ResponsesInList.Title: JavaScript utility to upscale images
ResponsesInList.Text: If anyone wants to try this, feedback appreciated. https://github.com/RVC-Learn-Digital-Team/moodle-javascript-upscaler Basically all background and foreground images > 100px get a hover upscale button (which ever corner of the image is closest to the mouse). Upscale is not AI. For a proper Moodle plugin (could be added to local_accessibility for example) it would need button configuration options and ability to switch on and off. But it works and can be pasted into administrator appearance extra html (with <script> tags) or downloaded.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: I have studied more than twenty courses across four different Swedish universities and higher education institutions. Despite the differences between them, they all share the same weaknesses in how Moodle is structured and presented. As a student with ADHD, I often experience that perception and navigation in Moodle become barriers in themselves. To better understand my difficulties, I have also used ChatGPT to analyze how my own perception interacts with the learning platform. This showed me that the problems are not purely personal – they are systemic. Key Challenges Important details disappear in complex file structures. Key documents are sometimes reused but remain hidden in folders named after earlier modules. Unclear file names (e.g. “document1.pdf”) and inconsistent naming of resources. Long and complex course pages where crucial information gets lost. No standardized course template – every teacher organizes Moodle differently. As a result, I sometimes spend entire working days just trying to orient myself in the file structures, or contacting teachers for help. This takes away focus from learning and wastes valuable teacher time. What is Needed What we are really asking for is standardization : Clear coding and labeling of documents/resources Each file should include a code and a full “path” in the course structure (e.g. Course Geography1 → Module 1a → Assignment 2 → document2.doc ). Adopt a standardized course template across the institution Same predictable layout for every course (intro, resources, assignments, forum). Consistent naming conventions and metadata . Built-in support for time orientation A function that clearly shows how many hours/days remain until assignments are due. Why It Matters Without such standards, Moodle courses do not meet current European accessibility legislation (the Web Accessibility Directive, soon strengthened by the European Accessibility Act). For students with ADHD, this lack of structure creates unnecessary cognitive barriers. Standardizing Moodle use according to clear accessibility principles would not only help students with ADHD – it would support all learners by creating clarity, predictability, and compliance with legal requirements.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: "Without such standards, Moodle courses do not meet current European accessibility" If teachers can create courses some will create inaccessible content. As you say this goes way beyond people with ADHD. I have realised recently that I have a problem with the most mundane of physical interfaces. Despite having the same cooker for about 5 years yesterday I turned on the bottom oven and five minutes later it is cold because it is not clear which button does what. I could give other examples which mystify my partner. The people at Brickfields do some interesting stuff about accessibility. Disclaimer I have known them for a long time, like them and know little beyond "interesting stuff" though I ought to. Could you expand on what you mean by "A function that clearly shows how many hours/days remain until assignments are due." it sounds interesting, the fact that time passes still comes as a surprise to me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your reply, but I think we should be careful not to trivialize the issue. In my experience this is not about a few individual teachers – it is a systemic problem that I have encountered at several higher education institutions where I have studied. Interestingly, I have not had the same difficulties when courses were delivered in Canvas. We should also not downplay the fact that many teachers simply do not have the time to learn the platform, do not receive sufficient training, and are often unaware that their choices in structuring Moodle can make learning virtually impossible for students with impaired working memory or selective attention. At present, students are forced to keep entire folder structures in their head to locate relevant documents. This is made worse when teachers are careless with file names, or even use different names for the same document. That is why I am suggesting a document ID system – for example added as a suffix in the filename – so that each resource can always be identified, regardless of naming. The part you found interesting – the visual “Time left bar” – is inspired by the gaming world. It could show the due date as a live countdown in days and hours until submission. Such a feature could add a useful layer of gamification, but most importantly it would provide clear temporal orientation for all students, not only those with ADHD.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: This i both exciting and scary at the same time: Summary There is currently a significant lack of research and empirical evidence on how people with ADHD actually perceive and navigate digital environments. Most existing studies focus on outcomes (e.g., screen time, distraction, difficulties with self-regulation) rather than on the subjective perception and user experience of digital platforms. As a result: Knowledge gaps remain – we lack robust frameworks and systematic studies addressing ADHD-specific interactions with digital systems. Adaptations are missing – digital accessibility standards (like WCAG) focus mainly on visual, auditory, or motor impairments, while ADHD-related needs are overlooked. Responsibility shifts to the individual – instead of platforms offering built-in adaptations, people with ADHD often have to “cut and paste” together their own strategies, tools, and methods to make digital systems usable.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: "but I think we should be careful not to trivialize the issue." I really really did not mean to trivialise the issue, I gave a real world example of something in my direct recent experience to illustrate this is a problem well beyond a tool like Moodle. . You are correct it is not about a few individual teachers, it is about a huge number of teachers/course creators who are unaware of the issues and "just want to get the job done". Canvas have put a great deal of effort into this area, but I am confident that it is possible to produce courses with accessibility issues with that as well. A visual indication of time left for things is a good idea and also technically not especially hard to implement. I was a teacher for 10 years and saw at first hand how easy it is to create content that leaves students lost and mystified. I cleave to the principle of "don't make me think" I have been thinking about this for a long time, but I have great deal to learn.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thankyou for the insights here but as you say one size fits all approach will not work and most of the issues you have raised are an instructional design issue and not one that can or should be addressed in the system itself.  I have a good understanding of the challenges ADHD can bring living in a household with several members who have varying levels of ADHD, and all that brings so please understand this is where I am coming from. A long tagging system for file names is problematic as it will break a lot of teaching use cases and can be confusing for screen reader users. The timer we have past experience with them in quizzes and many students with anxiety particularly would find having a countdown to their next submission extremely stressful and would negatively impact their results.  There are some long disucssions in the quizzes forum around this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Disclaimer: I have been recently diagnosed with Attention Deficit Disorder (by a certified psychiatrist) , which I have had since childhood. Moodle Academy has three very, very good free courses about accessibilty: * https://moodle.academy/enrol/index.php?id=58 * https://moodle.academy/enrol/index.php?id=45 * https://moodle.academy/enrol/index.php?id=54 I have added a Spanish translation of these (Creative Commons) courses to an optional complete (160 hours) 'Moodle teaching for university lecturers'  at my University (UNAM), and they have been tagged as the most important subject of all.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thats truly a great suggestion thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Summary and reflection from a student perspective I want to be clear that I approach this solely from a student perspective — focusing on how design choices affect students’ experience, cognitive load, and access to materials. I don’t fully agree with the previous comment that these issues are purely instructional. Depending on how the question is framed, they are also system problems. The way the platform is designed either increases or reduces the chances of mistakes, and that has a direct impact on students. Take file naming as an example: tagging systems sound useful in theory, but in practice they are inconsistent, confusing for screen readers, and too dependent on teachers’ technical skills. A strict, purpose-driven naming convention — built into the system — would create predictability and reduce errors. And this, in my view, is just the first step in a broader, step-by-step change where each course component is clearly framed to support even those instructors who are less interested in digital structure. From here, we face a choice: either maximize flexibility and accept higher risk of inconsistency, or reduce complexity through enforced conventions and guided workflows. From a student perspective, the latter is far preferable: it should be hard to do things wrong, not simply possible to do everything right.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: The Moodle project has focused on maximum flexibility from its start around 2000, I don't see that changing significantly.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: The issues we face with our learning platforms aren't just "instructional" problems; they are fundamental system design failures that directly impact our experience. The way the platform is structured determines whether it increases or reduces our cognitive load and the chance of errors. My central point is simple: We need a shift in design philosophy from "maximize flexibility" to "reduce complexity through enforced, guided workflows." ​ The Flaw of Flexibility and the Engineering Mindset ​The current system's focus on maximum flexibility, which often feels like an "engineer's mindset," treats usability as secondary . It creates an environment where, while it's technically possible to set everything up perfectly, the complexity means it’s all too easy to do things wrong. This leads to "configuration overload" and wildly inconsistent course experiences, which is a massive, unnecessary burden on students. Our focus should be on knowledge transfer , not on mastering complicated software. ​ The Necessity of Enforced Standards ​We need the system to incorporate governance and guardrails . Essential elements like a system-enforced naming convention for files would eliminate inconsistency, instantly improve predictability, and ensure better accessibility for tools like screen readers. Institutions must prioritize a standardized, recognizable course structure to ensure a minimal learning curve . The choice is ultimately between flexibility (high risk/inconsistency) and enforced conventions (low risk/high predictability). From the student perspective, the latter is vastly superior because the system should make it hard to do things wrong. ​ Predictability as an Equity Requirement ​This need for predictability goes deeper than general usability; it's a critical issue of inclusion . A teacher can work a lifetime and still not fully grasp the specific perceptual needs of students, particularly those with neurodevelopmental differences , such as an ADHD brain . For these students, the platform's inconsistency—a disorganized folder or a confusing label—is not a minor annoyance; it's a significant, energy-draining cognitive barrier . This means that a minimal learning curve and reliable consistency are not a luxury; they are an absolute necessity for equitable access. ​

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Flexibility has been baked into the core of Moodle since the start and it is now a vast enterprise with around half a billion user accounts globally.  The things you say may be true but a wholesale reset of its design principles and focus is simply not going to happen. With that in mind you might consider what incremental changes could help. For example in your original post you mentioned Long and complex course pages where crucial information gets lost. No standardized course template – every teacher organizes Moodle differently. For 1 there have been features and plugins with features to attempt to address this in the past, and others might like to comment on how this has been addressed. For 2 imagine if a clean fresh install of Moodle gave an option to install a course on "Learning to use Moodle", that came with a well designed course template and it was possible to have an option that each new course created came with a default template based on a global setting but with an option to select from a bank of course templates/layouts. What do you think?

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: for #2, I use the Course Templates plugin and it's very helpful. But as you said, all of this is possible with plugins, that's the point... no one-sized fit all to force on everybody, just let users select the plugins that work best for their organization/situation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Your point is that Moodle can be made more structured through plugins, but this depends on whether each institution allows and installs them. Just because the functions exist does not mean they are actually used in practice. It was only when I started doing my own research that I realized such plugins even existed — this is not something universities ever talk about. I have also heard about a plugin that can download multiple files at once, which could potentially be useful in the development of standalone applications. The discussions here have led me to realize that I may need to develop a tool where people with ADHD can restructure downloaded material from Moodle themselves. Since Swedish universities also tend to switch learning platforms every few years, it seems, as usual, that we have to take matters into our own hands if we want real order.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your thoughtful reply. I understand your point about Moodle being designed for maximum flexibility and that a full redesign is unlikely. Still, I can’t see how teachers realistically would have the time to learn and apply Moodle-specific training courses. Most of them already struggle to balance teaching with their own research and administrative duties. In that context , expecting them to master course templates and structural conventions feels unrealistic. This is why I am leaning towards creating external structures outside Moodle – based on downloaded materials – where students with ADHD (and others) can organize content in a way that reduces the cognitive burden. From the student perspective, this often feels like the only practical solution. That said, I also wonder whether I am missing something: do schools and universities not already apply standardized course templates on the teacher side? As a student, I only see the “front end” of Moodle, and it is often chaotic. I would genuinely like to understand if the lack of structure is because templates do not exist at all, or because they are optional and inconsistently applied. In general, I am positively inclined toward open source and flexible features, but in this case my main aim is simply to figure out the cause-and-effect relationship behind the current course design practices. Without knowing why courses look the way they do, it is hard to know whether the solution lies in better system defaults, stronger governance, or external tools.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks John, I will have a play with that plugin.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: It is good practice for organisations to employ someone with experience in learning design who understands the issues. Without the right knowledge people will work around technologies designed to promote good practice. One version of the Moodle editor was designed to push people towards accessible content but some people put effort into work against and around that. Good course design and standardisation is far more a human than a technical issue and requires education and knowledge.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Johan, these are all good questions. I guess it really depends on the school. I have worked with a few that all have employed some type of "Instructional Designer" that was in charge of aiding the teacher, setting up a template course, and working with the teacher to input their content. I've been lucky to be in these environments. I know there are are schools where it's only the teacher working on their own course content and unless the administration had a unified system in place to have the LMS administrator copy a course template over for them to work out of, then yes you are correct that teachers are essentially 'on their own' especially without adequate training. In my current environment, when a teacher clicks the "Course Request", I create their blank course and then I import a "Template" (which is a course that just houses all the consistent visual setup of activities ). The "Course Template plugin allows other users to copy that course template with out needing me to do it for them, so that plugin is very helpful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle forms, hideIf and accessibility
ResponsesInList.Text: On Moodle forms, it is common for there to be some form fields that depend on other field. For example in the Forurms setting form (link to Moodle demo site) , in the  'Common module settings' section, if you change the value of 'Group mode' then the ' Grouping ' setting underneath appears and disappears. For screen readers, we seem not to do anything special for that. For example one could imagine that being marked with aria-live="polite", but that example probably illustrates why we don't do that: the other thing that changes is the next thing in tab-order, so what happens should make sense to users of assistive technology. But, what about in other cases, is there a case for making it clear to screen-reader users that changing one setting is having some impact on the rest of the form? I would be interested to know what people think.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle forms, hideIf and accessibility
ResponsesInList.Text: I think it might be nice to just read out some text with the label(s) of any revealed fields in this case. Something like 'Form control Grouping now available' and possibly (does this need announcing?) 'Form control Grouping now hidden' Just using aria-live: polite on the actual controls being revealed wouldn't make sense as it would just read out the labels and values - like you turn that on and it suddenly says 'Grouping', what's that about. (It's actually not too terrible in this case, but imagine it when multiple controls are being hidden and it will read the full text of all of them.) The same approach could be used for 'disabledIf'. It is possible to achieve this using aria-live, hidden (screenreader only) text, javascript to write the sentence when needed, and some new language strings. But it doesn't seem the sort of thing that accessibility advice normally recommends, so I wouldn't implement this without getting more opinions... --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I have an issue with recording audio files. I recently discovered that my hosting provider has disabled access to MP3 files, and my recordings are in the MP3 format. As a result, I can't play, access, or download them. Is there any solution to retrieve these MP3 files, perhaps directly from the directory or through the use of a plugin? Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, you can serve them from a different web server . You could run your own web server and upload the mp3 to a place where it serves the files. Then go to every place on your Moodle where it serves a mp3, change them to a URL , something like yoursite/upload/audio.mp3. Alternatively, you can upload them to some kind of media service like, YouTube, Vimeo, Odysee, Peertube, .. Be aware that then the participants are able to see the URLs and share them with non-participants. As you see, the root cause of the problem is your provider. You have to find a provider who allows the type of files you need. Next time he'll say no PNGs, what will you do?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: Okay, so there's no way to download the raw file directly from the directory and save the test recording in a different format?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: What do you mean by "raw files"? The mp3 you've uploaded to Moodle? Sure they are there, not converted to any other format. They have just been renamed to a hash of their content and in moodledata/filedir/ab/cd/abcdef1234..... You can find their original names and many other information in the Moodle database and can do what you want with them. If the provider supports a different audio format you can't just replace the files, since the new files will have different content hashes and new names too (counting the file extension). As I always say, the Moodle repository is convenient for the end user, a nightmare for the system administrator. BTW , the above is to my knowledge and what immediately came to my mind. There could be more practical solutions which I'm not aware of (and willing to learn).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the support and insights regarding my Moodle issue. The mp3 files I’m referring to are recordings from a student speaking test, captured using Moodle’s recording feature and saved as mp3 files within the platform. I don’t have these files stored locally, as they exist solely on Moodle’s file system. I’ve cloned my Moodle site to a different server that supports mp3 files, maintaining the same versions of Moodle, PHP, and the database. I also performed a search and replace to update the URLs. Most elements are functioning well; however, during my review of the recordings, I noticed that while some audio files play correctly, others do not. The affected files show an error message: “Hmmm… can’t reach this page. It looks like the webpage at mydomain/recording might be having issues or it may have moved permanently to a new web address.” If there is a way to resolve this discrepancy, I’d greatly appreciate any advice. Thank you again for your help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: > I’ve cloned my Moodle site to a different server that supports mp3 files You did the only right thing: If the hosting doesn't support what you want, then you're stuck. The workarounds I mentioned are big workarounds and if you get mp3 from students recording answers straight on Moodle interface, you can't be fishing them and uploading somewhere else. > I noticed that while some audio files play correctly, others do not. That could be a new (unrelated) problem. (You don't know whether these mp3 were broken in your original site, since it never allowed playing any mp3.) My understanding of media files and players are limited. I'd prefer you post this as a new discussion, maybe in the General help forum to get the widest attention.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: I regisered to test drive this function. I used different codeks before. I will write back on the results.

ResponsesInList.Title: Mark up of language menu with lang attribute
ResponsesInList.Text: We have recently undergone a comprehensive accessibility update. One of the items that was identified was that we are missing the lang attribute for each language on the dropdown selector for language. The "Français" link on the English page and the "English" link on the French page are missing the lang attributes. Does anyone know how I could easily fix this with something added to the Additional HTML section? or some other workaround? I know that this is addressed in Moodle 4.5 but we are not quite ready to upgrade to this so I am ideally looking for an interm solution. Moodle 4.1.9 with an Adaptable theme

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mark up of language menu with lang attribute
ResponsesInList.Text: That isa good point. The way to get this fixed is to create a bug report in the Tracker. https://moodledev.io/general/development/tracker

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessibility and usability forum change
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, We've recently created a new forum in Moodle in English - User experience (UX) - which you are welcome to subscribe to. Usability discussions can now take place in the new UX forum and this forum can be for Accessibility discussions only. I've moved a few discussions into the new UX forum. Please let me know if there are any other discussions you think should be moved.

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax and screen readers
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello I've posted in the Mathematics tools forum but with little traction so thought I might try here. Are there known issues with MathJax compatability with screen readers? All the documentation for Moodle says it should just work (and has done for many, many versions), but I'm finding that it is entirely skipped by the screen reader as being almost non-existent.

ResponsesInList.Title: Course Index
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Accessibility People! Could you vote for my Course Index issue on the tracker please? I recently revisited an earlier post I had made and realised I needed to give a clearer explanation. Essentially, when navigating through the accordion menu in the lefthand Course Index, the current state of a collapsed or expanded item is not read out to the screen reader user. Instead the next action they might wish to take is read out. So for example, if a Course Index item is collapsed, "expand" is read by the screen reader. This can be confusing for the user as can lead them to think the item is expanded when it is collapsed. We think it would be better if the current state of an accordion item is read out first and then the action of expand or collapse is read out if they go to activate it. Also, when the user expands an item with the space bar, you hear "space" and not "expanded" and when the user repeats the action you hear "space" again and not "collapsed". Many thanks for your support. Hope it is ok to post this here. I am new to this forum! Kerry

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle blocked in certain countries such as Iran and China?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello! I am with the World Cube Association that hosts speedcubing competitions around the world and are getting ready to install Moodle for training. We have Delegates (speedcubing officials) based in Iran and China and are wondering if certain countries block Moodle access. Thanks in advance! Dan Smith

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle blocked in certain countries such as Iran and China?
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle can be hosted internally, hosted on Chinese or Iranian servers - so it depends on who hosts it and whether that hosting company is blocked by China or Iran. I can't imagine there is a default blocking of Moodle software.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle blocked in certain countries such as Iran and China?
ResponsesInList.Text: I just want to say that it makes me very happy to hear that the WCA will be using Moodle. I taught a nephew to solve cubes, and so ended up taking him to a cubing competion for his birthday. He had a great time, and I was impressed with how well organised the event was, and how friendly and inclusive was the atmosphere. So whatever training you are already providing to organisers seems to be working. Anyway, if all the work I have contributed to Moodle over the years can help make it even better, then I am pleased.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle blocked in certain countries such as Iran and China?
ResponsesInList.Text: I doubt countries specifically block Moodle, but there are countries where access generally can be problematic. About 8 years ago I worked for a UK company that had many clients in China and there was always a background issue of "The great firewall".

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle blocked in certain countries such as Iran and China?
ResponsesInList.Text: When you say "if certain countries block Moodle access", what is Moodle in it? Do you mean those countries block sites running Moodle? Where? Inland or abroad? When I think of the Great Bamboo Wall of China, I imagine something very sophisticated. Filtering based on the domain names and IP ranges are the minimum. They must be doing content filtering too. I heard that they are allergic to a certain nickname of the president of the country. ;) The software running those sites are also relevant, but I think they look for software that allows to share content anonymously apart from the dark web and other illegal operations than at educational platform like Moodle, which in its core knows only the usual SSL encryption (HTTPS). I would say people in the Security and privacy forum know better.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle blocked in certain countries such as Iran and China?
ResponsesInList.Text: We have clients in China with Moodle sites hosted both inside (alicloud) and outside the country. We haven't had any issues and performance has been OK even when hosted on servers hosted outside China.

ResponsesInList.Title: Links in Main Menu Have tabindex="-1"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I've noticed that in Moodle 4.4.1, the links in the main menu have a `tabindex="-1"` , making them inaccessible via keyboard navigation. This seems to conflict with best practices for accessibility, as users relying on keyboard navigation or screen readers are unable to interact with these links. Could you clarify the rationale behind this decision? Is it intentional for certain use cases, or might this be an oversight? Additionally, what would be the recommended approach to make these links accessible while maintaining the intended functionality? Thanks in advance for your insights!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Links in Main Menu Have tabindex="-1"
ResponsesInList.Text: If you are refering to the Dashboar and My Course links they are accessible using the arrow keys and act more like a sub menu/tab items than individual link items although visually I can understand the confusion. This is to speed up keyboard navigation for the majority of use cases where they are options that are seldom utilised

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Links in Main Menu Have tabindex="-1"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Brett, Thank you for the clarification! I’ll add this to our site guidelines to help users navigate more efficiently. Thanks again for your insights and your work on improving Moodle!

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding Alt Text to Image File Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello. How do I add alternate text to an image that is a file resource in 4.3? Also, is there a way to add alt text to images in a folder resource? Thank you, Laurie

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Alt Text to Image File Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: I know the Banner or Course image is supposed to be decorative but some instructors find crafty ways to make it meaningful - so would be nice if descriptive text was offered there also, the same with a profile picture. To try to help with a short term solution, when you add images into a folder resource perhaps a ~readmefirst file could contain that alt or descriptive text if it is not included in the image.

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessible Computer Programming Code
ResponsesInList.Text: How do I add an example of programming code to a Moodle course that is accessible to blind students? We are on Moodle 4.3 and use the ATTO text editor. Thank you. Laurie

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessible Computer Programming Code
ResponsesInList.Text: Laurie Moodle should work out of the box with most screen readers so nothing special should be required. That said is there a specific issue that you have encountered here?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessible Computer Programming Code
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Laurie. Have you tried enclosing the code example inside a `<code>` tag? You'll have to edit using the "HTML" view in Atto to do so. The `<code>` tag should be enclosed within a `<pre>` tag for multiline code examples. Doing so should let assistive technologies know that the content is computer code. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessible Computer Programming Code
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you, Jun.

ResponsesInList.Text: An example how to modify UX: https://moodle.org/ux An example for a paid LMS: https://kajabi.com/

ResponsesInList.Title: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there Moodlers, We recently had to disable the Accessibility Block ( https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/Accessibility_Block ) on our version of Moodle 3.9 as it posed a major security risk. Having looked more closely, it appears that it is no longer supported, but we weren't aware. And there is no Moodle 4.1 version - we are upgrading to Moodle 4.1 in the next few months. In terms of a replacement, I have seen talk of the Brickfield Accessibility Review block, but that is for teachers, not students. I would usually encourage students to use the many tools within their web browsers to change font size, contrast etc. But we have a particuarly difficult Degree Apprenticeship course that has very strict criteria for students when they are engaged with the VLE. So is there a replacement for the old Accessibility Block? What are others doing? Many thanks in advance for your help. Catherine

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Catherine, I had the same question. Did you find a solution or are you still without an accessibility plugin?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: There are obviously various sides to this challenge: First of all, faculty or instructional designers / education content writers should adopt UDL (Universal Design for Learning) good practices when designing their content in any LMS. Fortunately, there are a lot of resources to help with that. Then, existing content can be checked and improved using tools such as the Brickfield Accessibility suite. Following that, it's up to the participants to work with this content and use whatever aiding technology they need. Keep in mind that most current laptops have pretty good tools on board to help with accessibility issues, that are quite a lot better than what the TTS / Accessibility block had to offer. And finally, there are specialty integrations available, such as ReadSpeaker, which can be added to provide online and state-of-the-art text-to-speech solutions in multiple languages. From my personal experience, I can recommend this tool (comes at a price, though), because it not only offers text-to-speech for all course content, but also provides a user-friendly document viewer/reader for all text formats in your course (PDF, MS Office, Open Office, ...).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: PLEASE NOTE : the Accessibility Block ( https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/Accessibility_Block ) plugin is no longer being actively maintained by us at Brickfield. The main challenge is with the third-party external ATBar, which is not being maintained at all by its authors, at some point has lost all of its docs, and doesn't have an up-to-date SSL. If someone has funding, and would like to cover the updating of this plugin, we would be happy to engage with you on this. We are planning on sharing a new plugin which will provide guidance to users with their font size, font colour, and other display options, depending on their browser. We will update this forum discussion once it's available. As Joost rightly pointed out, there are many good tools now in both devices and browsers to help with accessibility issues!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Catherine, I built my own plugin for it. It is modular in terms of the widgets inside, so you can choose what you want to enable (or develop). https://moodle.org/plugins/local_accessibility Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: How compliant is Moodle 4.4.1+ (without any plugins) with WCAG 2.1, ARIA 1.1, and ATAG 2.0? And how does its compliance change when you install plugins?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello - just moved this to the Accessibility and usability forum. Just checking you have seen the documentation Acessibility and the VPAT Accessibility conformance report?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the the VPAT Accessibility conformance report. Do you also know something about ARIA 1.1, and ATAG 2.0 ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't sorry, but hopefully someone viewing this discussion will be able to comment further.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks anyway , you were of great help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Ben Moodle uses aria labels and other technologies to meet the WCAG requirements.  For the most part if a product is WCAG compliant you don't need to worry about the technology it uses to achieve it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: "And how does its compliance change when you install plugins?" It is not possible to answer that question because the people who create Moodle have no control over plugins used. It would be possible to create a plugin that is not accessible and people might install it, but that would be a plugin by plugin issue.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Ben. Moodle 4.4+ meets WCAG 2.1 Level AA. With WCAG 2.2 released in October 2023, we also aim to meet WCAG 2.2 Level AA conformance for future releases of Moodle. Re: ARIA - We use the appropriate ARIA tags/roles for our user interfaces whenever applicable. Re: ATAG - We currently do not evaluate against ATAG 2.0. However, The accessibility audits also evaluate Moodle's text editors (Tiny MCE and Atto) against WCAG Level AA to ensure their accessibility. Moodle's text editors also provide authors with the means to create accessible content. For example: Ability to designate headings in the text content Ability to create accessible links and images Provide the means to attach captions to uploaded media content Accessibility checker tool for the authored content Moodle also has a built-in accessibility toolkit that organisations can use to help them create accessible course content As Marcus said, Moodle HQ has no control over the accessibility of third-party plugins. So, it will be up to the institutions installing the plugins to evaluate their accessibility. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Missing new certification link
ResponsesInList.Text: On this page: Accessibility | Moodle Developer Resources is a link .to the WCAG 2.1 Level AA conformance. Yet this link leads to the Target conformance WCAG 2.1 Level AA from the 3 May 2023 and not the Target conformance WCAG 2.1 Level AA from the 24 January 2024. Does somebody know where the Target conformance WCAG 2.1 Level AA as of 24 January 2024 is ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Missing new certification link
ResponsesInList.Text: See the user docs VPAT Moodle accessibility conformance report. The Statement of Accessibility Conformance is at the bottom of that page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Missing new certification link
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Ben. Our accessibility audit provider has been acquired by another company, and it seems they no longer update the list of accessibility accreditations they issued on their former website. Instead, we have updated the link to the URL of the Statement of Accessibility Conformance issued by our accessibility audit provider on the Accessibility page of the Moodle Developer Resources. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Announcement to mobile users only
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it possible for an announcement to be seen by mobile users only? The announcement, of course, would be, "This website is best viewed and used in desktop mode." Thx

ResponsesInList.Title: Announcement to mobile users only
ResponsesInList.Text: If in a Text block, you could add a custom CSS class to it -- then use CSS to only show the block within certain screen dimension example: @media only screen and (min-width: 768px) { /* Hide Block with this class in non-Mobile Desktop View */ .custom-class {display: none;} }

ResponsesInList.Title: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: Good evening, We have a moodle 3.9 with several online activities . Normally each of them has 3 open questions where they are answered with free text. When it comes to corrections, it becomes very tedious since you have to go to each response item per student, and when the popup for said response opens you have to click on rate to be able to enter a score/feedback and save. This multiplied by 3 questions for each student and 150 students is a horrible number of clicks. We would need to continue with the online questionnaire format since we have implemented a staggered entry that allows the system not to collapse. The alternative of uploading a file instead of an online assignment has been tried but it causes more problems than the one we use since there are problems with the students due to the format of the file and the possible closure of the activity before they upload it. With the online activity, it is sent automatically when the time is up even if the students do not click on the send button. The problem at this moment is basically the teacher's task to correctand how to make it more bearable in some way by maintaining this type of activity but reducing the number of clicks to correct. Any ideas? Greetings.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: Use a quiz and then the manual grading option which allows you to mark the entries of all students in one form instead of opening many single windows.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: Using a quiz the way Matthias suggests is probably most convenient to go along with what you are currently doing. However, any time you are wanting to have students write "free text" you might want to try out the Diary plugin.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank your for your response. But the professor must see the student response to each question before grade then they have to do every click to check the answer and after that do the grade manually as you say. The best option is to use a rubric but the quiz don't have this option.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: So, it appears that your only problem with uploaded files is that students use different software. You can: 1) prescribe the software they must use, such as Word, text, Google, Pages, etc. Give them about three choices: Word, Google Docs, or Text. 2) train your instructors about how to open these different file types.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: The text format (*.txt) is quite universal. You might not even need additional text files, the text can be typed straight in to the assignment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Where to find ALT tag in Database

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where to find ALT tag in Database
ResponsesInList.Text: They are stored in the database with the content the image is in. And, content is stored throughout the Moodle database, e.g. mdl_page.content, mdl_question.questiontext, mdl_question.generalfeedback, ...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Self activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Now I better understand. Essentially, you want a "teacher" role, however, you want teachers only to be able to edit their own work. Interesting question. I am not sure why, but you have your reasons. Also, I can't think of any solution except to explore "roles" setting. Perhaps someone else will know.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Self activity
ResponsesInList.Text: I am pretty confident, that this is not possible. Creating or editing abilities is only being controlled by the capability moodle/course:manageactivities. A role has this capability in course context or not and thus can edit activities or not. The data which user added an activity is not even recorded somewhere AFAIK (except logs), so it would be very tricky and/or would require a big development effort including deeper changes to the Moodle core code to realize such a feature.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Self activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Based on what I know and what these other users have mentioned, I think the only way you can achieve something close to what you want, would be to give each of your users their own course with the role of teacher in it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Seeking Accessibility Tips for Moodle Navigation with NVDA
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey everyone, I'm looking for accessibility tips on using Moodle with the NVDA screen reader. I need suggestions for shortcut keys that can enhance navigation. If anyone has cracked this, please share your insights! Thanks in advance for the help. Best regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeking Accessibility Tips for Moodle Navigation with NVDA
ResponsesInList.Text: Kael, are you looking to add shortcut keys to add to Moodle or what existing shortcut keys exist? It would be good to get a better idea of what you are trying to achieve From an accessibility point of view Moodle should be fully navigable via keyboard already. In general any sort cut keys need to ensure that they do not interfear with screen reader keys.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeking Accessibility Tips for Moodle Navigation with NVDA
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your response! I apologize if my initial question wasn't clear. I'm actually looking for any existing shortcut keys within Moodle that could enhance the accessibility for visually impaired users who rely on screen readers like NVDA. Your insight that Moodle should already be navigable via keyboard is great to know. However, I was specifically wondering if there are any keyboard shortcuts that can be utilized to improve the user experience for those who use screen readers. I understand the importance of not interfering with screen reader keys, and my intention is to identify any potential shortcuts that can complement the existing accessibility features. If you have any suggestions or information on this topic, I would greatly appreciate it. Thank you again for your assistance!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeking Accessibility Tips for Moodle Navigation with NVDA
ResponsesInList.Text: Kael For the, most part there are not keyboard shortcuts within the system but Moodle does provide "Skip to content" links and similar for screen reader and keyboard users to speed up navigation. TinyMCE text editor has a set of keyboard shortcuts which can be found under the help menu when it has focus which are also useable.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeking Accessibility Tips for Moodle Navigation with NVDA
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your response and suggestions. I appreciate your effort in providing solutions for improving accessibility in Moodle. However, I've tested the 'Skip to content' links and other features you mentioned, and unfortunately, they don't fully address the needs of users who are visually impaired and need to read content and complete quizzes. I was specifically looking for keyboard shortcuts or other tools within Moodle that can better assist users with disabilities in navigating content and interacting with quizzes. If there are any additional insights or resources you could provide in this regard, I would greatly appreciate it. Ensuring a fully inclusive learning experience is a priority, and any assistance you can offer will be valuable. Thank you again for your time and help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeking Accessibility Tips for Moodle Navigation with NVDA
ResponsesInList.Text: We are always looking at ways to improve the accessibility of Moodle. The current versions have just undergone a WCAG audit and we are addressing gaps there at the moment. If you have other suggestions I would love to hear more so we could consider them for future improvements.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Edit Mode
ResponsesInList.Text: "Adding" a course differs from "editing" a course by adding activities and resources. You don't need to be in "Edit" mode to change administrative items, such as adding a course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessibility audit
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, During our internship at Bordeaux INP, we conducted an accessibility audit of our institution's Moodle platform. Although we were able to make some changes on our end, we do not have access to the complete code, limiting our capabilities. Here are the main issues that we believe are important to address: Information is lost on certain pages (especially the Dashboard ) when stylesheets are disabled. Tables within courses cannot be linearized (e.g., participants). It would be necessary to add a role="presentation" attribute in the HTML code. Empty and unnecessary 'h' tags have been overlooked in several places. There is no notification to alert users when a new page or tab is opened (e.g., when accessing a course file). We appreciate your understanding and support in resolving these accessibility concerns. Best regards,

ResponsesInList.Text: Which version of Moodle please?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility audit

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to link to a collapsible topic

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Please let me know if Moodle is compliant with the following: ADA (American Disabilities Act) FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act) GDPR (European Union's General Data Protection Regulation) CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act). Thanks, Abhiram Y.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: What have your searches found so far (so people don't duplicate the information you have already found)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: The answer is largely yes but it will strongly depend on your configuration, instructional design, and course strucutre/enrolement processes. This will be true of most LMS.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Abhiram and thank you for your question. I can confirm that Moodle is compliant with: FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act) GDPR (European Union's General Data Protection Regulation) CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act). However, we can not confirm compliance with the ADA (American Disabilities Act). Moodle's software can be downloaded and used globally, and as Brett says, amended by the end user in many ways, and thus we can not review all the policies applicable to the use of Moodle in all possible contexts. If you would like to provide us with a summary of the legislation in question, we would be happy to provide a high level opinion of Moodle's compliance therewith.

ResponsesInList.Title: What is the purpose of a flag in Quizzes?
ResponsesInList.Text: For the first time in ca 12 years, someone- a student - has flagged a question, probably because she doesn't understand the response options. I cannot see any use for this piece of information and have never considered using it. Since for this course, it seems a redundant piece of information, can I remove this option from the design of the quiz (all of them) as presented to the student? Thank you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the purpose of a flag in Quizzes?
ResponsesInList.Text: Another name for a flag is a bookmark - it's just a way of indicating a question that you want to return to. You can remove the option for students to flag questions by removing the flag question capability (moodle/question:flag) for the student role (at site, course or activity level).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the purpose of a flag in Quizzes?
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is a video that I share with my students. It contains information about how the "flag" feature can be used (Moodle 3.11).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the purpose of a flag in Quizzes?
ResponsesInList.Text: If you want to remove it from students, that is controlled by a capability, and you can change which roles have which permissions. But, as the other posters have said, there is no one purpose to the flag. It's a simple feature that can be used in various ways (or ignored).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the purpose of a flag in Quizzes?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you all for your help. This has clarified its role. We usually get feedback about a question by a direct message/email from the student, which has worked well for some years. Velson

ResponsesInList.Title: Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit link error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I am using the Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit and I'm getting errors on links that are set to open in new windows. I've added explanatory text, such as " The Library of Congress website (opens in new window) will provide you with research information to complete your project." However, the error is not clearing in the Error List. Does anyone have an example of how they've corrected link text to clear the error? Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit link error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Elizabeth, many thanks for your question. With the Brickfield Starter checks, the only way to stop it showing up in the report is to remove the “open in new window” option. We will update our starter language string appropriately in the next update. To provide some background, there are very few valid reasons for forcing a user into a new window and there are many reasons why you should not do so. I love one quote from the Nielsen Norman Group , or NN Group, an industry recognised World Leader in Research-Based User Experience, "Opening up new browser windows is like a vacuum cleaner sales person who starts a visit by emptying an ashtray on the customer's carpet. " Here are some reasons why you should not force links to open in new windows For everyone, bouncing people into another window is a surprise and not a good one (like a box of chocolates). This will further create problems for users with low sight or cognitive disabilities who may not see that a new tab has opened. Opening a new window or tab resets the back button in that window. Users with screen readers cannot go back to the page they came from. This breaks the navigation experience for that user. Whenever someone clicks a link they should be able to go back. The back button is a heavily used feature in browsers. If the person is using a terminal - they force one window only generally, so putting a link into a new window literally means they cannot navigate between windows/tabs and will either lose the existing site or not access the new link. Navigating multiple windows/tabs is a pretty horrible experience and can cause a lot of confusion on mobile devices - especially phones - this is not an experience you want to force on your users The core, starter version flags these issues for your action. With our Premium product , we have helpers that offer different ways to handle opening links in new windows. In short - let the user decide if they want to open a link in a new window or not - and perhaps add “(external site)” as text so they can tell if it’s external.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit link error
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit link error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Elizabeth, we have now submitted code via Tracker MDL-75404 to enable this feature as requested! If you'd like to review its details and even vote for it, that will show its benefits for those doing peer reviewing, to hopefully get it approved and integrated into the next Moodle minor release.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit link error
ResponsesInList.Text: Wonderful, thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Logs by Role/exclude Site Admin
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I've been using Moodle for a number of years now, and often look at the logs to see how new cohorts are doing and get a general overview. However, if I have been making adjustments to the site/courses etc, it can quickly get swamped by my own actions. It would be very useful if we could have a feature to either show logs by role group, or exclude Site Admin/some user. Is that something that might be possible?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Logs by Role/exclude Site Admin
ResponsesInList.Text: Currently, the only option to improve this is to make your own SQL reports, some examples of which are in the Ad-hoc contributed reports page . We can hope that in the future the new Custom Report Builder in Moodle 4.0 will have some reports that allow us to filter data from the logs, but we do not have those yet.

ResponsesInList.Title: block plugin won't appear without manually add
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi guys, I want my plugin visiblt to all users not only admin, without any manual work. Is it possible? I know how to edit my main page and add a block. Do all users need manually add the block to their main page? If yes, it's unreasonable let all students do this to see a student related block plugin. I didn't find any guide on docs plugin part. Please help to comment. Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: block plugin won't appear without manually add
ResponsesInList.Text: 1) You either let all the user add the block on your own in their dashboards or 2) you go to the default dashboard setting and reset the dashboard for all users. Be aware that the second option will overwrite all the individual settings of the users. Option 2 might also take some time to perform (depening on how many users you've got in your system).

ResponsesInList.Title: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a way to customize the core web pages within Moodle (like the forgot password page, course overview pages, etc.)? I need to be able to customize the ALT text accessibility of these pages . For example, the close button on some pages reads “Times sign” by a screen reader instead of the close window. Also sometimes the screen reader focus is out of order on some pages (reading items at the bottom of the page first, etc.) And yes I have checked Moodle documentation, plugins, and all my admin settings and I do not see any options for this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: Whenever you believe there are alt-text issues with any Moodle graphics, report this as a bug in Moodle Tracker . They should be fixed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: As Rick says, that is a bug. ALL alt text should be in the language pack as a language string and you should be able to change and customize that as usual. It should never be hard coded. You can verify whether an alt text is hard coded or is a proper language string using the Debugging tool to show origin of language strings . Focus is a separate issue from strings, that's a theme problem, and should be reported too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried to check the language pack but maybe I was doing it wrong. Do I just search for the alt test that is wrong? So in the example above, search for "Times sign" and replace it with close?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: Kim, Yes, if it is wrong then you can change it for your own Moodle instance by putting what you want in the Local customization field for that particular string. The details are in the documentation for Language customisation . This only updates it for your site, not for core Moodle, so reporting errors is still important so that the language pack maintainers, which for default English is Moodle HQ itself, can fix those.

ResponsesInList.Text: Not sure if this has been asked elsewhere, but I couldn't find anything in the searches.  Does anyone know how we can add a "status" to the course page when an activity has been submitted but not yet marked?  (in Moodle 3.11)  This would be in addition to "Done" and "To Do" status' that currently exist. We're using the assignment activity to have users upload documents and then have an assessor view the document and mark it.  In the course, the student can see whether they have yet to do an activity (it will be marked "to do") and whether they have completed an activity (so it's been marked).  It will show "done".  But is there anyway to show "submitted"? This is particularly relevant if they're using the app, so they can't access plugins like Completion Progress. Thanks for anyone's thoughts on this.

ResponsesInList.Title: De-activate Brickfield in course?
ResponsesInList.Text: We are testing the Brickfield version accompanying Moodle 3.11. It seems to work fine, and I think it's a great feature, but I have a few questions: Once a course has chosen Submit for analysis, the Brickfield analysis cannot be de-activated for that course, is that correct? To hide all the analysis information from the course page, one has to add the Accessibility Review block and use the view/hide button? Is there any way for the teacher to set specific warnings to be ignored? I do think the teachers would like to have the continous monitoring as an option, and most of them would prefer to mainly check the accessibility now and then. And teachers wanting to try out the accessibility check and deciding not to continue using it, will get annoyed by not being able to completely remove it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: De-activate Brickfield in course?
ResponsesInList.Text:
HI Peter, Sorry we missed these questions. You can remove the block and it does not show to the teacher, however
once analysed it stays in the database and updates the status as things
are added or edited. Yes,
if they have the heatmap on, and go to a course which is analysed it
shows, a bit like some other features of Moodle which maintain state
across things. No there isnt
a way for a teacher to do that, however this is something we offer in
our July release of our paid subscription product.  Although "ignore" is
not  the term we use, its hiding . The
Accessibility Starter Toolkit is a small subset of our paid for
subscription, and therefore does not have all the features of our paid
for product as is the normal in the fremium/premium type models Also
in our end of July Subscription release is an alternative report view
of the "heatmap"  as it only works on the  weekly/topic and this
alternate report will have a view for other formats too. this way the
"state" of the heatmap is not turned on at all. We have some fixes/changes in our queue to improve starter, however none of the things you mentioned would be effected. Regards Gavin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: De-activate Brickfield in course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you, Gavin!

ResponsesInList.Title: Run Brickfield Accessibility Toolkit for a Second Time
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I am on Moodle 3.11.7. I have run the Accessibility Toolkit once and it returned a number of errors. I have now corrected these errors and I want to run the toolkit again to check that I have corrected everything and not introduced more problems. How do I do this please? Thanks, John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Run Brickfield Accessibility Toolkit for a Second Time
ResponsesInList.Text: The toolkit runs through scheduled tasks which run on cron. If you want to make the re-analysis happen faster, you can make those tasks every minute or two minutes. Regards Gavin Co-Founder of Brickfield Education labs

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Run Brickfield Accessibility Toolkit for a Second Time
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks v much. I hadn't realised that the report was re-run automatically based on scheduled tasks. I see now coming back to it a few days later that it has indeed re-run. Thanks for a really great tool.

ResponsesInList.Title: Hide resource / activity by profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 3.9 Is it possible to hide a resource / activity by profile field criteria? Currently you can restrict access according to profile field criteria and the tile / resource / activity is still shown as greyed out. This leaves a cluttered looking page. Example My use case is for parents to manage access to resources for their children. (I don't create child accounts) Named certificates, quiz, results etc are duplicated in each instance according to how many children they have. If they have one child (as defined in their custom profile field) I want the Child 1 tile / resource / activity to display If they have two children (as defined in their custom profile field) I also want the Child 2 tile / resource / activity to display However, if they only have 1 Child, then I don't want the Child 2 tile / resource / activity to display. Or, if Child 2 has only been entered to take part in an activity, I don't want the Child 1 option to display. So is it possible to hide a tile / resource / activity by profile field or hide if restricted. Thank you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hide resource / activity by profile field
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you using the "eye" icon to hide the restriction to those who do not meet it, as explained in the documentation ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Can students access content without having to download Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, I have tried looking for an answer but could not. Can students access a course online without having to download the package? Thank you very much, Riccardo.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can students access content without having to download Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: No students have to download Moodle to access it - you are on a Moodle site now and you didn't have to download it, did you? It is just a website. If you mean can students access a course online without having to download the course materials - well that very much depends on what your course is made off. Feel free to give more details if my answer is not helpful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can students access content without having to download Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Mary, thank you. I mean if they can attend a course composed of any activities (assignement, file, H5P, URL ,...), and teachers maintain the possibility of interacting with them (grading, answering,...), without students downloading Moodle (I need this information to understand hardware requirements for students). In case they can access the course only as a website as you say, can you please tell me (or show me if you have a link to some resource) where would they find the credentials page to log in? Thank you again a lot and please excuse me for the silly questions! Riccardo.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can students access content without having to download Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Students don't need to download any software to access a Moodle course (unless you want them to use the mobile app on their smartphones)To access it on the internet as a regular website you just need to allow them access. Have a look at the video "How can new users access my Moodle site?" in the page Admin quick guide and if needed also look at the pages related to Enrolment. You might be interested in the Admin Basics courses on Moodle Academy too

I assume that I would use the standard Moodle folders, but I am not sure of the process.  I manage the PD Moodle instance myself on the Bluehost site, so I can get to the filesystem through Cpanel. 1) How should I add files to the courses so that they are in external repositories that can be archives and reinstalled with standard Moodle processes in another Moodle instance? 2) What commands would I use to archive these external files so that they can be delivered with the mbz file? 3) What process would be involved to upload the mbz file in a different Moodle instance, and then make visible the folder containing the files associated with the mbz files? Thank you in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course design to simplify uploading the course/files in a different Moodle Instance.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Is this the same setup as in your earlier enquiry Design of MoodleCloud Grades 7-12 multi-course site, so files are archived in .mbz ? If so, then the fact that the school sites are off-line is an important detail. Incidentally a somewhat similar request is being discussed in the MoodleBox list. See Share multiple files at once . BTW , what was the conclusion of that earlier enquiry?

ResponsesInList.Title: Additional time setting (override) on all activities
ResponsesInList.Text: In my university students can get "reasonable accommodation" e.g. for neurodiversity. One of the measures is to give them additional time on all activities where anything needs to be completed. On the quiz activity there is a way to deal with this and I e.g. put every participant who gets 50% additional time into a group "half extra" and that works fine. I would like this group override feature generalized so it can be applied to any activity that has any deadlines in it. The trickiest case I can think of right now is in the workshop activity where an override for the submission of a student A would need to cascade to an automatic override for any students B who is the evaluator for A. Ideally, that override for B would only be for those evaluations that have themselves been overridden not for the evaluation of submissions from a student C that does not have an override for their submission.

ResponsesInList.Title: Bulk Topics Creation
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I need your help, I want to create a course using the CSV and it worked fine now I would like to know if there is a way to upload the topics to the course in a simple way like a csv file.  Any idea would be welcome Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bulk Topics Creation
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Luis, If you have the same amount of topics per course, you could set up a template course and then specify it in the CSV file as the course to copy/clone. Of course this wouldn't give you complete granularity on naming the topics-per course etc. Hope this helps. Anthony

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Keyboard Access/Screen Reader text on Interactive Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Marcus - CC = Closed Captioning. What I meant by keyboard accessibility,  screen reader users use the tab key to access content like a Quiz and select a radio button or checkbox, this ability is lost in the course. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Keyboard Access/Screen Reader text on Interactive Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Can you check the javascript console to see id any errors are shown and paste them here. https://linuxhint.com/javascript-console What is the difference between the tabbing order as it should be and as it is now. Do you have a small example you can post here for other people to test?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Keyboard Access/Screen Reader text on Interactive Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Screen readers have difficulty accessing content in iframes. The SCORM activity has an option to control how the material displays. Under Appearance heading you can select whether content displays in same window or in a separate window. When displaying in the same window the content is actually displayed embedded in an iframe with Moodle headers and blocks. Opening in new window opens a new window without the inframe or extra content that is more accessible, but may be less convenient for other reasons.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing headers in list of users
ResponsesInList.Text: Marc, Only by changing the code, unfortunately. The setting "Default user filters" only affects the filters, not the columns. And the settings for "Show user identity" and "Hide user fields" do not apply to the Browse list of users, only to things such as the Participants list, etc. This would be a nice feature to have. Perhaps in Moodle 4.0, the new Report Builder will be able to do this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Participants filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 3.9 includes a new filter design on the Participants page. This is quite powerful and I can see some benefits for it when filtering by multiple characteristics. For simple filtering though, it adds a lot more clicking to achieve a result. Our most common use for a filter on the participants page is to identify students in the course. This was achieved with two clicks in 3.8 by selecting the filter drop down and then choosing 'Student'. In 3.9 this requires five clicks to achieve - Select the data filter field, select the 'Roles' data type, select the Roles input field, select Student, select Apply filters. It would be good to be able to set defaults for this filter so that a commonly used search was quickly available to users. For our site this would be Role/Students so a teacher wanting to just see the students in their course would only have to select Apply Filters. If they want any other search then they would go through the process as normal. I haven't been able to find any settings for this in Site Administration. Should I be able to set site defaults? Does this seem like a reasonable request?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Participants filter
ResponsesInList.Text: I also believe a default participants filter would be extremely useful and if anyone knows an answer to this I'd be interested as well

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Participants filter
ResponsesInList.Text: This reminds me about the same discussion that we have had about activities . It is about the trade-off between more "power" and "simpler." Moodle "activities" (e.g., quiz, forum) are very powerful and flexible. Along with this flexibility, there are many items that can be adjusted. What has been requested are "templates" that could be configured that capture your most favorite settings, and then can be applied as needed. So, we see the same thing with the Participants Filter. We now have a lot of power and flexibility, but it takes a little more to get everything set. It would be nice to have "templates" where one should set up their most favorite filtering criteria. I would like to see both. But until we have templates, I still favor having more features so that I can get to what I want to have.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Participants filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Our campus could make use of the default participant list filter as well, although having one we could configure as admins would be sufficient. I have submitted an issue on Tracker: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-72763 .
