ResponsesInList.Title: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it possible for the tutor / teacher on a Moodle course to change the status of a submitted quiz from submitted to unsubmitted so that a student can continue working on their attempt? I have been asked to raise this by a tutor at our university. The quiz in question was set to 1 attempt only. A couple of students needed to be given the chance to reattempt the quiz, We know that you can set a user override for a student, for example, giving them 2 attempts. You can also delete a student's attempt within the quiz results screen so that they can then have another go. However, is it possible to simply change the status of the submitted quiz to unsubmitted so that the student can continue working on their attempt? If not, I don't know if it would be possible for something like this to be added in some future iteration of Moodle? Or, are there very good reasons why this is not a good idea? Any answers on this, even if this is just to explain the rationale for not allowing a tutor to change a students submitted quiz from submitted to unsubmitted, would be really helpful and I can then go back to the tutor with what can be done or a reason for why this is not possible. Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: The difficulty is that when a quiz attempt gets marked as submitted, it is not just a simple change in the quiz_attempts table in the database , but also normally some updates in the question_attempt and question_attempt_steps tables for all the questions in that quiz attempt. It is possible to undo all the database changes that happen when the attempt is submitted, but it would be a bit fiddly to get right, and so no-one has had the time or inclination to implement it. However, it certainly would be a good idea to make this possible, but it is not going to happen until someone has a strong-enough motive to do the work. So: Good idea in principle. Only not been done before because making it work would be hard and time-consuming. In the mean time, just give students a second attempt.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Many thanks for your reply Tim. I will pass this back to the tutor.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kristian, I'm not sure whether this would answer your question, but it from Moodle 3.4 onwards, it's possible to override a student's activity completion status from the Activity Completion report. This should reset the number of attempts for a specific user, as the completion status returned to it's original value. As long as the quiz is available (no end date, or end date in the future), the student should be able to retake the quiz. https://docs.moodle.org/34/en/Using_Activity_completion

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joost, This is very interesting. Looking forward to trying this out when we get out next Moodle upgrade. We're on Moodle 3.3 at the moment. Thanks very much for your reply.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Removing bottom navigation links

On the Fordson theme you can hack the columns2.mustache file and remove this line: https://github.com/dbnschools/moodle-theme_fordson/blob/master/templates/columns2.mustache#L103 
```text
{{{ output.activity_navigation }}}
```

ResponsesInList.Title: AJAX errors after session timeout + Chrome restart
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, when you launch Chrome with a Moodle tab from yesterday still open you get multiple "servicenotavailable" error boxes. If you then reload the page, you get redirected to the login page. Users shouldn't see this "servicenotavailable" error if the problem is that they're not logged in. This occurs on Moodle 3.4.1 (Build: 20180115) running on CentOS 7.4.1708 with Apache 2.4.6, MariaDB 5.5.56 and PHP 7.2.2 when accessing it with Google Chrome 63.0.3239.132. I have already tested and debugged this and found out the reason for the error: In this case it is AJAX calls being performed while the user is not logged in. The user is not logged in because his last session timed out. Normally when he opens a Moodle page he would get redirected to the login page. However, what happens here is: Chrome opens the Moodle page when being launched because that page was open when Chrome was last closed. But it doesn't refresh the page by sending a new HTTP request which would redirect the user to the login page. Instead it displays the page as if the user was logged in which leads to the AJAX calls failing. How do I prevent this from happening? Just using  another browser or changing some browser settings won't work for us as we don't have control over that. I also don't want to "hack" Moodle's core code as that would make it harder to maintain. Any help appreciated, Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AJAX errors after session timeout + Chrome restart
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, Is the problem you describe covered by MDL-56896 ? If so, please could you comment on it. If not, feel free to create a new tracker issue.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AJAX errors after session timeout + Chrome restart
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Helen, seems like that's exactly my problem. I wrote a comment on it.

To support Moodle sites in the EU to become GDPR compliant, we have developed features which will be installed as plugins, initially, for Moodle 3.3 and 3.4. The features will then become part of Moodle 3.5 release which is a Long Term Supported (LTS) version of Moodle. We now would love your help to test the GDPR features and get feedback on what we need to improve by March 2018. What is involved? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lost in courses list after moodle change
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear A B, I understand your frustration about the UX improvements to Moodle, as it may look different from what you're used to. A constructive approach to solving your issues would be the best course of action to take. As far as I understand it, your main issues are with the new My Overview block that has replaced the old block Course Overview as core. This block can still be installed and used instead of the one you're somewhat unhappy with, if you're a systems administrator for your Moodle. If you're not the systems administrator, you could point the person in charge of this to the correct plugin, so he/she can install and enable it. There's just one caution: at some stage (in a little over 2 years), the legacy Course Overview block will cease to function, with the release of Moodle 3.7. I strongly hope that you will have gotten used to the new and improved My Overview block by then and that you can see some of the positives of this new redesigned block: - a timeline for detailed information on what's expected when - sorting courses according to Current, Future and Completed - more detailed course completion details - ...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course pages editting disappears
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sandra, Seems you have a lot (maybe even too much) media that has to be loaded on opening the course main page. In regular Moodle course formats like Weeks or Topics, everything is loaded upon entering the course, which may cause problems if there are a lot of huge files to process (image, audio, video). If there's a timeout because of the sheer volume of data to be loaded, you may need to have a look at how the media files are incorporated in your courses. Embedded external media works better than having the complete files as part of your courses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course pages editting disappears

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course pages editting disappears
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sandra, You could ask your supplier how those other sites have been configured. It could be that there's a memory limit setting that's significantly lower than what they're used to seeing in other sites. If that's the case, there's probably a few community members in the Hardware and performance forum you could consult.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Re-attempting assessments made in Articulate Storyline 2
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rach, Not sure if I am on the same page, but it might be worth checking to see if 'Force New Attempt' is set to 'Yes' in the Scorm settings in Moodle. If it is, then each attempt will be considered as complete and re-visits will be forced as a new attempt. I think...! This from the help: "This setting hides the "Start new attempt" checkbox and prevents review mode. SCORM allows a student to return to the same attempt at any point and a new attempt is not possible unless the previous attempt has been set as "completed", "passed" or "failed". If the SCORM package does not do this, the student will always re-enter the same attempt."

ResponsesInList.Title: Closing dialogues
ResponsesInList.Text: We were doing some usability testing, and we noticed that, when a dialogue was open in a page, some users were clicking on the grey background area, expeciting that to close the dialogue. Therefore, we created MDL-60207 to change Moodle to match users' expectations. Does anyone have any comments about that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Closing dialogues
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree, I would expect modals to close when I click in the grey background. It's always annoying if sites don't support that, because aiming for the close button is usually harder, especially on touch devices. There are exceptions, though. For example, critical warnings should not be dismissible by touching the background. In that case it is okay to raise attention to the message this way, as it cannot be closed as easily. Also, if a modal is a form, it would be too easy to close it accidentally by touching the background. I think in that case Moodle should also keep on relying on the close button (or buttons of the form).

ResponsesInList.Title: Cron in cluster environment after upgrade to 3.1.6.
ResponsesInList.Text: Good morning, everyone, We have a four Red Hat 7.3 cluster with Moodle 3.1.6 and I cannot figure out if we can schedule the execution of cron.php in all of them or we have to keep scheduling just in one. Moodle 2.7 Upgrade documentation ( https://docs.moodle.org/27/en/Cron ) shows the below information: Cron in Moodle 2.7+ Cron has received a major update and now has support for both scheduled and adhoc tasks - MDL-25499 . The benefits of these changes are: The schedule for every task can be configured by the admin. See Scheduled tasks Tasks can run in parallel Cron processes use locking to prevent the same task running at the same time by different processes A result of this is that cron can be run much more often, which means (for example) forum posts can be sent out sooner. Admins can keep cron running at the same schedule as before, but it is strongly recommended that they increase the frequency of running cron to at least once per minute. But I don't know if the cron.php can be run in different servers since it can be run in pararell, or it just can run in parallel in the same node since it is recommended to run it every minute. Thanks in advance, Ángel

ResponsesInList.Title: Calling Teachers/Instructors with course editing rights to participate in Moodle HQ Usability Study
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Moodlers, Firstly, thank you for those who took part in our recent usability study, focussing on course administration settings in Moodle. If you would like to find out next steps with that piece of research, please refer to our post on moodle.org. We’d love to get your feedback, ideas and thoughts again! Now, we  would like to once again invite interested Moodlers to participate in another important usability study, running from Friday 11 August to Friday 18 August (note: the study will close 7:30 AM UTC Friday 18 August). We would like to hear from English-speaking Teachers/Instructors, with editing rights to Moodle courses (or administrators who frequently access Moodle course settings), to join a usability study that will help with future Moodle development. What’s involved? Involvement in this research study means: Spending  approximately 15 to 30 minutes trying out a prototype and giving us feedback, and/or we might interview you about your current experience using Moodle. A Moodle HQ researcher will set up a remote screen-sharing session with you on your own computer. Sessions may take place outside of typical business hours depending on your local time zone. We’d like to hear from you if: You can participate in the sessions online using Zoom Meetings (which involves sharing your desktop screen and audio) You have access to a microphone and a broadband internet connection You provide consent for Moodle HQ to record video and audio of your interactions using Moodle on your desktop screen. Please note: all video and audio recording will be strictly confidential and not be shared with anyone /other parties outside of Moodle HQ. If you’re interested in participating, please sign up using the link below: https://calendly.com/moodle/editing-teachers *Note research sessions will be run Monday - Friday

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Calling Teachers/Instructors with course editing rights to participate in Moodle HQ Usability Study
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey everyone, Thanks very much to those who volunteered for this study. Really appreciate the time and effort that many of you took to give feedback. For your information, we collect the data you provided to help us continue with our UX work in Moodle to make our learning platform interface more user-friendly and easy to navigate for our educators and learners. We still need more user feedback and experience to help us with the next stage of our work, so I’d like to invite you to a second usability study from today through to Wednesday 20 September. For more information and to sign up, please see this post https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=358290#p1445113 Thanks again everyone - look forward to working with you all again!

ResponsesInList.Title: Calling Teachers/Instructors with course editing rights to participate in second round of Moodle HQ Usability Studies

Your feedback has been super helpful to guide our UX work in Moodle. We’d now like to invite you to sign up for the second round of usability studies. This study is also open to new Moodlers or those who’ve missed out on the first round and would like to be involved! As always, we’d love to get your feedback, ideas and thoughts too! Once again, we would like to hear from English-speaking Teachers/Instructors who have editing rights to Moodle courses (or administrators who frequently access Moodle course settings) to participate. A Moodle HQ researcher will set up a remote screen-sharing session with you on your own computer. Sessions may take place outside of typical business hours depending on your local time zone. We’d like to hear from you if: You can participate in the sessions online using Zoom Meetings (which involves sharing your desktop screen and audio) You have access to a microphone and a broadband internet connection You provide consent for Moodle HQ to record video and audio of your interactions using Moodle on your desktop screen. Please note: all video and audio recording will be strictly confidential and not be shared with anyone /other parties outside of Moodle HQ. ResponsesInList.Title: Item visibility toggle ("eye icon") now hidden under a submenu?

I always start the year by importing last year's course and hiding the activities I don't want my students to see right away, so I use that toggle a lot and it was nice to have it next to the activity. Is it possible to move some of these actions back out so that they are more accessible? I've tried both the Boost and Clean themes but both behave the same. Any alternate way to change the visibility of a lot of activities without lots of clicking around would actually help. Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Item visibility toggle ("eye icon") now hidden under a submenu?
IFrame Size on URL resource
ResponsesInList.Text: In earlier versions of Moodle it was possible to set the size of the iframe that contained your embedded web page. Now you only have the option to embed the page. This causes scroll bars to appear on the embedded frame as well as on the browser. In the past I would adjust the height enough to cause the inner scroll bar to disappear. Sure would be nice if I could still do that! It would also be nice to be able to turn off the visibility of the frame. Does anyone know if there is a css file that can I can edit to make these changes? In the end I want it to look the same as a Page resource, nice and clean. Version 3.31 by the way! Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Better Workflow for Grading Lesson Essays

If a lesson has many pages with essay questions and one has a class with 20+ students, then the instructor has to click 100+ times to grade each student response for just a single lesson. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Better Workflow for Grading Lesson Essays
ResponsesInList.Text: If you have that many essay questions in an activity such as Lesson, wouldn't it make more sense to use the Quiz activity, which has a better workflow for manually grading essay questions? Lesson works well as a basic branching scenario, but isn't the best for grading such complex texts (I doubt it was designed to be used for this).

ResponsesInList.Title: Linking Activities to Each Other in a Topic
ResponsesInList.Text:
Is it possible to link activities /resources to each other in
a topic so that once activity 1 has been completed it automatically brings the user to activity 2 instead of automatically bringing the user back to the course’s
main page? Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking Activities to Each Other in a Topic
ResponsesInList.Text: You could add links to the next activity .  So...quiz overall feedback includes a link to the next activity (maybe a lesson ), and that activity includes a link to the next, etc.  The only one I think won't link well is SCORM --it will automatically redirect to the course home.  It might not be ideal, but it would work.  If you copy courses over for new years, you would have to fix the links for each one, but it would function. There are a couple course formats that might do that as well. One Topic and Grid are two I've looked at.  Maybe Buttons.  Those three look...promising.

ResponsesInList.Title: A simple dashboard block for file download
ResponsesInList.Text: As an administrator I want to expose a dashboard block to all users which contains files (pdf, word, etc.) that any logged in users sees and can view and download the file from. Any good suggestions? Moodle 3.3.1

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A simple dashboard block for file download
ResponsesInList.Text: While not exactly what you want, some themes have a "This Course" drop down which displays a listing or grouping of activities and resources.  For instance if you click on Resources from this course menu it would list all files, books, pages, and resources.  Not exactly what you want but close. What's nice about this is that it also shows what topic the file/resource/activity resides in. This type of functionality helps quickly locate a quiz or assignment when working in large courses.  Having the topic also helps give the user context for the resource/activity.  Fordson, essential, adaptable, and others have this built in.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A simple dashboard block for file download
ResponsesInList.Text: Are these files you will have added for them to download? Perhaps you could use an HTML block, add it to the default dashboard for all users and upload your files into that block as links?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A simple dashboard block for file download
ResponsesInList.Text: All, I am using the html block. Its working exactly the way I need, and found out today this can be on the dashboard layer as well as the course layer. Thanks, Dan

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm wondering why it is not possible, at least in my Moodle instance (3.1) to hide the navigation block for the Guests?  I have already changed the permissions for the navigation block, capability: moodle/block:view and changed the defaultroleid on the frontpage to guest. It doesn't have any effect at all. The navigation block still appears. Any suggestions? Best regards Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hiding navigation block on the frontpage
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried this on our sandbox site demo. moodle.net . Please see Blocks FAQ I didn't change the default front page role. I turned on the editing and went to the navigation block and then Permissions and clicked the X to remove guests from being able to view the navigation block. When I logged out again, non-logged in users (ie anyone who just comes to the site) do not see the navigation block.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hiding navigation block on the frontpage
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Mary, thank you for your prompt reply. This is exactly what I have done. Nevertheless this problem appears in my instance, so I need to carefully check my system configuration. Thank you and best regards, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hiding navigation block on the frontpage
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul Did you try removing guest view permissions of Navigation block within Front Page Settings ? I tried removing guest view permission from the Navigation block on another page and it did not work. Only when I removed guest view permission from the Navigation block within Front Page Settings did Navigation block stop displaying on the Landing page. Charles
role: Picture of Charles Krengel eLearn Solutions

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hiding navigation block on the frontpage
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul, I realise this is old now, but it may help others as I've stumbled across it from a search - I think the reason yours was not responding to removing the guest permission from the navigation block was probably due to either one or more of these settings being something other than the default values: Site administration --> Front page --> Front page settings --> Default frontpage role Site administration --> Users --> Permissions --> User policies --> Role for visitors *and* Role for guests I am not 100% certain which combinations would work in your specific scenario, but the removal of guest permissions on a block has the desired effect when these settings have default values. Regards, Martin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to download the attached file to the quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: The quiz doesn't have an upload function as this is what the Assignment module is for. However, a way around this would be to use an essay question and leave instructions for the student to upload their file as a link within the essay's text box. I.e. click on the "Link" button on Atto's toolbar and click "Browse repositories" > "Upload a file" to upload their file into the text box as a link.

ResponsesInList.Title: Activity Completion Tracking
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I'm posting this under usability as that's where it is a problem for me - but forum admin might decide it sits better elsewhere. I have courses with groups of students undertaking separate activities - lets call it differentiated learning. I'm preparing for upgrade to version 3.3 and want to fine-tune activity completion so that the course notifications are more accurate. Currently it works as follows - when students view a resource, take a quiz or whatever the completion box is ticked and it is tracked on the activity completion report. Unfortunately, the activity report doesn't take account of whether a student is permitted to access a resource - it just lists everything that has a completion option, even if the student isn't able to complete (for example because they don't belong to the only group with access). Once we move to 3.3 I'm anticipating this might go catastrophically wrong, with students panicking as Moodle tells them they've only completed 1/3 of the course activities, but they can't see anything that they haven't done. What I think SHOULD happen is that when the activity report displays, it is individualised for each student. If as a result of activity restrictions a student has no access to an activity, the report should have a gap (instead of a tickbox that will never be ticked) - and that the completion notifications and tracking should likewise only consider the activities available to that student, regardless of what else might have completion tracking switched on in the course. Can anyone enlighten me about whether this issue has been addressed in the 3.3 version of Moodle - or if there is a workaround? If there isn't a solution I'll raise a bug report as this will impact really badly on student perception of the new Moodle progress notifications if it hasn't been thought through. It's bad enough as staff wanting to check progress and having to constantly refer back to see why students haven't completed tracked activities, it'll be far worse if students are being told they haven't done something they don't have access to. Regards, Gordon.

And if one has to change it cannot be done. Right now it is all manual , a new user registers, I add them to the right cohort(s) which is synced to the course. If they change cohort I have to do it manually. The problem with this is that I am never aware of when a new users registers or makes a change . So I end up with half users in cohorts the others half floating around which makes them invisible to the ones supervising the grades of their groups. What I want : User registers and chooses cohort from dropdown menu on profile, automatically added to cohort which then adds to course/group. If user changes cohort (from dropdown menu on profile) they are then deleted from the old one and added to the new one. Simple . To take care of the grade loss all users are in a general cohort. Everyone is in that one to make sure all info is kept in case they are deleted from another cohort. Is there anyone who as a way to do this? Is it something that can be done ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle System Message Troubles?
[3.2] Mass send e-mails with logins and passwords to manually createdusers
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings everybody. I just finished making my first moodle site and I would like to know if there is any way to easily send mass emails to manually created users. I'm am aware of the bulk user action e-mail, but is there any way to make it so each user gets individualized info with his own credentials? I'm also aware of CSV file, but people I made the site for want something easy to use. Also the password cannot be randomized (with I guess would be easiest as this one has automatic email sending). One thing is I'm pretty much incapable of scripting and coding to save my life, so please bear that in mind before you tell me to just change the source code. I searched the web for info about this particular feature in moodle, but nothing I found was satisfactory.

ResponsesInList.Title: Odp: [3.2] Mass send e-mails with logins and passwords to manually createdusers
ResponsesInList.Text: I think I figured it out: Site administration > Plugins > Enrolment > Flat file (CSV) You need to enable the enrolment Flat file plugin first, then go into its settings and check "Notify enrolled users" . The site started sending e-mails after that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Course view VS program view
ResponsesInList.Text: I've searched through the forums and didn't come up with anything on the topic.  I work for a medium-sized university and have often been asked how to make Moodle more "program oriented", as opposed to course centric.  I'm looking for ideas on how to make it more clear to teachers and students what programs they are enrolled in and simplify navigation between courses that make up a program (or several different programs...). Could this be done using a customized block that would be added to each course? Could this be done by customizing the "My" page so that, instead of showing a long list of individual course, it would show a program container/section, under which individual courses would be shown under it? Some users have used meta-courses to create "program home pages" and then enrol other courses into them, but that only adds another site to a user's "My" page and doesn't really help them know where to go. I'm interested to know what others are doing to address the issue.  Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course view VS program view
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Marc, Have you considered trying to use tags? Tags can be added to a course on it's setting page. Seems like a "program" tag could be added to each course of a "program". When someone clicks a program tag, they would then see a page listing all the courses with that same tag set. Also, many of the activities are getting tag capability in Moodle 3.3. Not sure if it would be practical, but might be worth testing. Also, there is already a tag block so it would be easy to test/try out and see if it would work.

ResponsesInList.Title: New K-12 Easy Enrollment when LDAP or External Database is not Used
ResponsesInList.Text: At K-12 we have a usability issue with getting our youngest and sometimes our oldest kids to the proper course with the proper enrollment key and finally, enrolled in a course.  We do not automate enrollments beyond LDAP authentication since teachers use Moodle for a variety of reasons which we don't want scripted. Sure you can use a CSV file but better be sure you have all your commas in order. We have long dreamed of having a simpler way of getting kids into courses where they do not have to browse or search 100's of courses.  Bigger sites create headaches for younger kids. We are in the process of developing a new enrollment plugin which mimics the functionality of Google Classroom and Edmodo.  It is almost 100% functional now but we are testing still.  It uses 6 digit codes that are entered on the homepage of Moodle and instantly enrolls the user into a corresponding course or group within the course.  It also functions independent of other enrollment plugins so you can utilize manual or even self enrollment if you desire.  This plugin ignores those enrollment keys and uses it's self generated codes. We believe this will greatly simplify getting kids from the homepage to the learning content. To take this one step further... we can even enroll students with a QR Code!!!!!! Video coming shortly as we just got this functionality working.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New K-12 Easy Enrollment when LDAP or External Database is not Used
ResponsesInList.Text: QR Code Working:

ResponsesInList.Title: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: As a Moodle support person I've been a bit concerned about the number of years that now appear in the pop-up menu when someone needs to set a date for something. The default is from 1900 to 2050, which puts 150 options in the list. In most cases dates are set in the future, and as Moodle is used for teaching they are not set very far in the future. I'd suggest that in most cases no more than 5 years are needed in that list. Currently it seems that changing the default years involves changing the 'code' in .../moodle/calendar/type/gregorian/classes/structure.php, lines 81 to 97. Are there cases where such a large range of years is needed? Is there an easy way to change the default years, for those who can't access the code on their server ? If not, I'd like to propose adding the default dates to the config file, which I have tested out on a local Moodle server. Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: Depends where that code is called (can't say I've looked into it). For example, what about peoples date of birth or history questions or date started at a company etc.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: These days, it is controlled by get_min_year and get_max_year in calendar/type/gregorian/classes/structure.php . Not sure what else would be affected if you changed that. Since it defaults to the current year, normally you don't have to scroll far to find the year you want in the menu, but you can still pick dates a long way in the past or future.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Just H. Can you point to some exact pages in Moodle with examples? Thanks Mal.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Tim, It is a minor issue but the huge list is cumbersome, it shouldn't be if it's not necessary. I can see this particular date selection form in several settings pages for Assignments, Quizzes etc. In all those places only a small number of years is needed. Know of any other places? In the Admin pages, we can add a date field to the user profile. In that case the min and max years can be selected from a list (drawn from the default min_year and max_year). So we can assume the date form function can respond to local variables as well as the default ones. So seems to be variuos possibilities for setting these years? Mal.

ResponsesInList.Title: Website Administration - different languages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, I upgraded from 2.6.2 over 2.8 and to 3.2. I changed the design to boost. Now, I have the problem that some elements (e.g. "my private files" or some points in the website adminsitration) are in English while I've set the system language to German. How can I solve this? Also some older courses are not shown in  "startsite/my courses" although I'm the manager. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Website Administration - different languages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, two issues here.... Not sure about the second - which in truth is completely separate from the thread title and should be posted on an appropriate forum. The first depends on if the points with the language issue are a contributed plugin or core.  If the former then you'll need to contact the developer to ask about M3.2 support via AMOS for the plugin.  If core then go straight to reading: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/index.php?title=AMOS_manual&redirect=no .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Website Administration - different languages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Solved it. Uninstalled language pack, reinstalled it and reloaded it. Works. Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Website Administration - different languages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Updating language packs is also possible if you manually run cron.php on your site. Saves you the trouble of uninstalling/installing.

ResponsesInList.Title: Error in PHP - Unsure what to do
ResponsesInList.Text: Good morning. I'm using Moodle 1.9 and getting an error. Here's what I am trying to do. When I click Include a Topic Section in Front Page settings and go back to the home page, I get this error message: Fatal error : Call to undefined function iscomplete() in /home/seamensc/public_html/course/lib.php on line 1442 I've attached the PHP script file. I'm not sure where the error is. On another site, the code is the exact same and I don't get the error. Anyone had this issue before? Can someone help me figure out what the issue is?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error in PHP - Unsure what to do
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lisa - This question really doesn't have anything to do with usability . This was probably a better question for the "General help" discussion. In any case, Moodle 1.9 has been out of support since July 2012 . It will be difficult getting help with it any more. Looking at the file and line you have mentioned in the code repository , there is no "iscomplete()" function call. I searched that entire file and could not find an occurrence of that call anywhere. I also did a search of the entire 1.9 codebase and could not find any occurrence of the "iscomplete" function. My guess is that you have made customizations in your code. And somehow you have lost some of those customizations. If you have another site with the same code at that line number, and it is working, then it must still have the customizations you need. Looking at the attachment you provided, the file has definitely been customized. It looks like it has the old "Activity locking" hack added to it (probably this - https://docs.moodle.org/32/en/Development:Activity_Locking#Table_of_Versions ). The function that hack provided has been part of Moodle since some version in Moodle 2. It would be best if you upgraded to a the latest (3.2). Hope this helps.

When searching for users to enrol, search engine of manual enrolment find exact string match or begins-with match, right? It doesn't find partial matches I guess. Is there any possibility that it can find partial matches? ex) When searching for users to enrol, if I search for "moodle" then I should be able to find "moodle" in the result. But in case I search for "odle" then also I should be able to find "moodle". Some faculty staff members inquired me on the topic above. They want to make partial matches possible. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Partial Matching When Searching for Users to Enrol
ResponsesInList.Text: I could solve this question by editing /enroll/manual/ ajax .php like this... $searchanywhere = get_user_preferences('userselector_searchanywhere', false); ↓ $searchanywhere = true; After editing and purging all caches, search engine of manual enrolment is able to find partial matches. Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello All, I love Moodle and I do love the badge function. However, our training department does training that need to be repeated every 2 years. For example the CPR and First Aid class is held every week of the year. Students are required to take this course every 2 years. I thought the best solution was to award a badge that expires after two years. It works great but there is no functionality to send out periodic emails when the badge gets close to expiring. Is there a way to do this? If i had to develop this myself where would be the best place to start? Thank in advance, Casey

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: Nobody wants to take a crack at this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: I had the same question and how I do it is rather than making the badge to expire, to date them. For example, somebody who passes the test for 2015 gets a badge "Yellow Belt 2015". That way the students are clear on the fact that the certification is limited in time, but they do keep the badge on their "wall of honor". I compare it to the scouts that collect badges on their shirt for all the years they are in the organisation. If they go on camp or to a jamboree, they sow that badge on, and it remains visibile.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: We're looking at something similar Casey - did you find / develop a solution in the end (reminders when a qualification is due to expire)? Thanks,  BJ

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: Take a look at the Reengagment plugin: https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_reengagement

ResponsesInList.Title: Show question type icons in the quiz manual grading overview
ResponsesInList.Text:
Description: In the list of questions of the quiz manual
grading the question number (Q#) and the question name is displayed. It
would be very useful if the question type icon would be displayed, too. This would facilitate finding certain questions especially when
manual grading is used for many questions and different question types
(essay, file upload , short answer, numerical ,...). Usecase: We use this when grading summative examinations where we don't want students to loose points for typos or grammatical errors in short answer questions. We also use it for calculated, simple calculated and numerical questions where a wrong decimal separator (comma for english language or point for german language) leads to zero points - although the student gave the right answer. Feature request: There is a feature request regarding this on Moodle Tracker : MDL-53814 Vote, comment, conribute: If you feel this is a helpful feature please vote. If you have further suggestions or an even better solution how to facilitate finding the right question, please comment. And of course it would be greate if someone could come up with a code solution!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show question type icons in the quiz manual grading overview
ResponsesInList.Text: Can you provide a screenshot please, so I can understand exactly where you want it and may provide you a solution.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show question type icons in the quiz manual grading overview
ResponsesInList.Text: Many thanks for the offer to provide a solution. Would be really great if this was possible. For the screenshot please have a look at the attachment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show question type icons in the quiz manual grading overview
ResponsesInList.Text: Paul, I've just submitted a solution.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show question type icons in the quiz manual grading overview
ResponsesInList.Text: The second usecase - giving points to students who entered the correct value with the wrong decimal separator in calculated, simple calculated and numerical questions - is no longer an issue. This is fixed at least since Moodle 3.0.4. However, there is another usecase where this feature would be helpful. There are question types (e.g. qtype_kprime) where students have to select options as in multiple choice questions. Even if teachers try hard to create unequivocal and unambiguous options, they sometimes only realize after the exam that an option specified as wrong in certain cases might be correct. To be able to give points to those students who selected this option, manual grading is needed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, We've discovered an issue on our site as we were conducting an accessibility audit. the alt= tag does not seem to work when you add an image and provide a description. This has been confirmed by our provider who are just as puzzled as we are. Out moodle version is Moodle 2.6.2+ (Build: 20140424) After a bit of trouble shooting, I changed the code to title= and the description showed when you hover over the image. As it is important for us to be compliant, I am concerned that using this workaround is not suitable. 1. Is using title= ok? It does cause more work! 2. Why wouldn't the alt= be working as it should? Many thanks! Jamie

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: alt="..." is working exactly as it should. alt is short for 'altenative'. The text is there for people who cannot see the image. alt is nothing to do with tool-tips. title="" is for tool-tips, which are not very helpful for accessibility.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: Good Afternoon, I am having the same issue with the ALT tags not becoming visible on mouse roll over. I have checked and they are present however even the ALT tags embedded in the SCORM packages are not showing up. I have tried in Chrome, Firefox , Opera and IE but am running out of ideas. I know you have said the tags are working as they should, is there a setting on Moodle that may not be activated? Any information would be fantastic. With Hopes, Leticia

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: Alt tag is not the same as a tool tip. If you want a tool tip, use the title="" attribute.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, Thank you for your reply. I have been out of the game for a while and did not realize title provides the mouseover text now. When I was coding originally it was one in the same using ALT tag. I have done some research and forgot to repost on my original query. I do have 2 other questions though: Do you know if there is a way to test the presence of ALT tags through a browser other than the inspect element function or screen reader function? and (this could be a long shot) Is there a way to add title tags in PowerPoint, so when they are exported using ISpring to SCORM or IMS packages they will show in Moodle? If you have any information i would be so so grateful. Thanks again

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, How can I check the ALT tags in a SCORM package in or out or Moodle? Thanks Leticia

ResponsesInList.Title: Points for enrolling in a course

ResponsesInList.Text: I have a course that is active on my moodle site.  Another instructor wanted to duplicate what I have and then modify it for his own needs for his course section.  If I go into the target course, and select Import, I know I can bring things from my course into his.  My question is this.  In my course, there are many files that are available and are linked from a file repository (I told it to create a link to the file, rather than a copy into the course).  The import into his course is taking a LONG time.  When importing into the target course, are these links re-created (ideally, this is how I would like it work), or are all of the files being copied locally into the target course? Any help would be much appreciated!  The import currently does not work, and I get the dreaded " error/cannot_finish_ui_if_not_setting_ui" error.  I have tried increasing my max execution time without success. Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi again.  I would like to give users of a non Moodle LMS access to SCORMs within my Moodle LMS. All users exist in both systems.  From the non Moodle LMS users are created and enrolled on courses by Moodle web services. Ideally Moodle would be invisible to these users with the SCORM popping up in a pop up. But I do need my Moodle LMS to keep track of progress, grades, number of attempts, etc. Has anyone any thoughts on the best approach to this or if there are any extentions that might help? Cheers Nigel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: LTI ; if the other LMS can handle it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: Just H tx for that.  The other LMS is a bespoke .net C# application and not LTI functional. But we do have full access to the source code and the development team so all things are possible. However our requirement is very precise and will not change in the future.  The resources in Moodle will always be single activity SCORMs.  The users will always be known to both LMSs.  Enrollment on to the Moodle courses is a hidden (to the user) process driven through the Moodle webservice. So I wouldn't want to use a sledge hammer to crack a nut as it were.  But equally wouldn't want to reinvent the wheel. Any thoughts on time taken to implement LTI would be welcome but in my experience these things are never as simple as they might seem in theory due to their generic nature. I was thinking more of having a link from the non Moodle LMS and automating the logon and opening of the relevant course.  As the Moodle instance will only have this task (the running of single activity SCORMs from this one non Moodle LMS) we do not have to be concerned by other types of processing, types of resource, and/or other requirements.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: Sadly development is not my forte but from what I gather from browsing various sites, for a developer it may not be as much as a black box as it appears to be to me. It may well be a sledge hammer approach but given your setup is half way there (from the Moodle side) might be worth your development team having a quick look to see how complex it would be. A couple of links that may be useful: https://www.edu-apps.org/code.html https://github.com/andyfmiller/LtiLibrary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: Just H links much appreciated. Yes for sure we cannot discount it as, as you say, we are half way there. And as we have the web services to register and enrol users, and to create courses we at the moment are not looking at changing Moodle code.  The only slightly against political correctness thing we have planned is dragging the results out of the Moodle database but that is of course read only.  So one advantage of LTi would be that it leaves our Moodle with code clean.

ResponsesInList.Title: Example: prompt to continue before performing an operation
Video formats for course pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi. Are there any video formats that are incompatible with Moodle, or can any footage be uploaded to a course page? Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Video formats for course pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Its not so much Moodle that you need to think about - its your users and their devices which may limit your compatibilty. Off the top of my head I don't know the formats that any built in player or 3rd party plugins will display, but I seem to remember from discussions that its fairly comprehensive. If in doubt, upload it to YouTube and embed it from there (restrict permission on the upload if necessary) - a. YT will take care of any device required transcoding b. you will save yourself considerable server space

ResponsesInList.Text: To expand on Richards comments, Moodle (or any web based application) does not actually play any video, it is the local device. Unfortunately the world of video formats is an utter mess and so I recommend Richards Youtube related advice.

ResponsesInList.Title: Better marking screen use
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm running a vanilla Moodle install, marking a basic text submission assignment on a 22" monitor and I have to scroll almost three screens full to see the entire submission and click the 'Save and show next' button at the bottom. This seems horribly inefficient. I'm going to wear out the scroll wheel in my mouse and get arthritis in my hand. Are there ways to get these marking pages set up more efficiently? There's no reason that valuable information should only start a 1/3rd the way down the screen. I shouldn't loose the students name off the screen when I actually get to the slot to put in the mark. And, I certainly should never have to scroll do deal with a one paragraph submission for a student on a 22" screen.  ...And no, I'm not going to zoom out 4pt font so It will all fit. How do I/we fix this? What can be done so I don't have to scroll so much? Marvin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Better marking screen use - OR scroll reduction
ResponsesInList.Text: I guess I should have written a better subject line. Just went through some more intensive Moodle marking in the last while. I still can't believe that I have to scroll around on a 24" monitor to mark a single paragraph. Is any work being done on formatting the default Moodle so that regular tasks have more of the information/options on the main part of the screen? Too often I have to scroll to deal with a single evaluation or setting change. Marvin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Better marking screen use - OR scroll reduction
ResponsesInList.Text: A lot depends on what part of Moodle you are in, but it is something that is being worked on. The grading interface for assignments is LOT different in the soon to be release Moodle 3.1. You can get a look at it if you go to https://qa.moodle.net/

ResponsesInList.Title: Why do we have to create our own navigation buttons in lessons?
ResponsesInList.Text: I am new to Moodle. Have been a Opigno user for a while, and while I like to streamline and comprehensive design, I do find certain things amiss. The most glaring is that I have to create our own navigation buttons for each lesson page. Each page needs either a back or next button, and all requiring custom naming of buttons. I understand that you can create custom internal links to select pages within the lesson, but can't the back and next navigation buttons be automatically generated? Surely it doesn't seem very complicated to implement, but would be extremely time-saving. Just a pretty big usability issue in my mind. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why do we have to create our own navigation buttons in lessons?
ResponsesInList.Text: Why not use the module book for this purpose?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why do we have to create our own navigation buttons in lessons?
ResponsesInList.Text: I presume its because the Lesson module isn't designed to only/primarily support a single path through the content where Next/Previous would be most appropriate. The Lesson module allows multiple paths through the learning to be created depending on selections made on different pages, so a previous button may need to take two different users back to a different place, while a next button may lead to one of a number of options.

ResponsesInList.Title: Popups in folders and decent file manager
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a pretty long thread here https://moodle.org/mod/forum/user.php?id=2074405 where I detail my struggles with organizing course structure while enabling say pdf popups. The gist of it is, why on earth?!!! can we not enable popups for e.g. pdfs, docx, images etc in anything other than main topics pages? The second whinge if you like, it really would be ideal if we could change file behavior from withing a file manager. Migrating from a 10+ year old platform, which although has a really diabolically ugly GUI, actually does all of the aforementioned pretty competently. Have had a look at plugins for enabling web-viewing of pdfs and word within the browser, as far as I can tell there are only a couple, which are reliant on third-party cloud hosting of files. Word is less important (and guess licensing issues apply), but pdf's are nearly universally viewable on most browsers regardless of platform (win, android, mapple, etc)...why is this such a problem for developers to address? At present, it looks as though you need a separate 'topic' for each subject where you want to enable pdf popups or on a separate browser tab. Thus instead of a course structure where you have say..main subject/theme/topic/subtopic (with pdfs, quizzes, external links, media etc), you end up with 100+ Topic/( activities , quizzes, documents, media etc). This structure may well work for 'week to week' course structures, but is far from ideal when you want the whole course accessible and navigable for students. Any ideas? Is it just me or do others find this laughable? How hard can it be to implement pop-up functionality of items within a folder/subfolder? Otherwise am really impressed with the platform...have used Blackboard and It's Learning way back when in undergrad and grad school (10+ years ago). Just not looking forward to having to restructuring the course into one 50+ topic long mess just to enable pop-ups. Doing this for a friend/client who doesn't want to deal with pages/atto editor...and with a lot of mathematical symbols, copying from word, can understand why. Copy/paste is not an option for maritime navigation course with associated charts etc! Would take months... Any plugins or suggestions very welcome! Just need students to be able to view pdfs in pop-ups, and have quizzes linked or in same secton.  Of course caveat being...around 5-7 'chapters', with 3-10 subtopics. 50+ topics with no organization seems pretty messy. Thanks appreciate feedback.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Popups in folders and decent file manager
ResponsesInList.Text: Addendun: for me at least, (and would think for many others), this limitation is almost a deal-breaker. Guess will have to make some calls to blackboard, it's learning etc to see what they want in licensing fees (which my clients really can't afford most likely!)...but as they say, money talks and bs walks! A shame as it seems this is pretty much one of the few limitations which prevents moodle from eclipsing aforementioned altogether.  The rest of the platform is really solid, and well thought out. But this (idiotic!) oversight is really holding it back... Essentially it limits moodle to short courses organized week-by-week, or where there just isn't that much content to be distributed. Am well aware it's free! and kudos to developers! Not all of us have access to institutional MS and Adobe licences tho.....!! Would be nice if the developer community could fix this...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Popups in folders and decent file manager
ResponsesInList.Text: Arne, I think you need to be more concise and specific as I have read through several of your posts and I understand very little of what you are asking. I understood the item "decent file manager" in your title, but then you didn't expand on that but I have no idea at all what popups in folders means.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Popups in folders and decent file manager
ResponsesInList.Text: Welcome to Moodle.org Arne. Your posts come across as a little breathless, I can tell you are frustrated, comments about Blackboard and calling people 'idiotic' (and appearing snarky) will not really win people's attention in the right way here on this forum where we are almost all volunteers. Be that as it may, I think I get your point, poorly expressed maybe, but I hear you saying Moodle is flat ( sections and no subsections), you just want to upload PDF's (none of the interaction Moodle is capable of) Have you looked at The Moodle Book resource? Have you seen Frankie's work? https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=322118 and http://moodurian.blogspot.co.nz/2015/11/view-pdf-files-in-pop-up-window-in.html Have you looked at the tabbed "One topic" format? Do you know what a course format is? Have you checked out navigation options like course menu plugin?  Or contents plugin? Do you know what a plugin is? I also am interested in within section navigation: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=316278 These are a few questions more or less at random, but you will get the point.  You do not indicate if you are skilled as a designer, coder, teacher or bits of each. Regards, and good luck. -Derek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Popups in folders and decent file manager
ResponsesInList.Text: If you can put your requirements into a reasonable structure, then I would suggest adding a Tracker improvement item. Other than that, I would suggest taking a look at some of the many repository plugins for your folder/subfolder/file structure as the folder resource is certainly not the only way to manage your large scale file resources for your course and may not be the most appropriate either.

If there is no - sign in 2nd answer then student only get 0,66 points. If I have understood right I cannot do like this with Moodle... ResponsesInList.Title: Adding Custom Grading Calculations
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all! I want to use Moodle to create a quiz but then "plug in" my own method for grading the quiz. I've done some digging into the source code and looked at add ons but I wanted to check in with the community to see if there are any recommendations or just "why in the world would you want to do that?" The reason for wanting to do this: I want to be able to analyze not just one answer but a collection of answers and then formulate a result from that collection. I will actually be creating a customized report from the analysis. Thank you in advance for your help! Best regards, Keith

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Custom Grading Calculations
ResponsesInList.Text: What sort of answers are you thinking of? Some existing question types already accept multiple inputs, and do the grading by combining them. E.g. https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_formulas or https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_stack . But, if you are not teaching maths, those won't be very interesting. So, option 1: consider making a new question type plugin: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Question_types Alternatively, if you want to re-use exiting question types (e.g. have an activity that combines answers to multiple choice questions in an interesting way, then you probably need to build a new activity module that uses questions: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Using_the_question_engine_from_module

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Custom Grading Calculations
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, thank you for the reply. I'm actually building an assessment where the user is asked to provide process results in terms of percentages. For example, "what percentage of widgets in your company can you locate at any given time?" So I take these answers, groups them into buckets that make up the system and then generate a report containing ratings of each of the buckets using statistics analysis. The challenge for me is being able to look at the answers in each bucket individually and as a whole and compare to other buckets. I hope I haven't lost you at this point! The questions types are more the sufficient to support what I need. It's the grading process I'm hoping to either customize or re-use something that is out there. Once again, thank you for your response. I will be looking into the links your provided in more detail.

ResponsesInList.Title: Track Changes for Collaborative Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all, Curious to get your reaction to a new feature idea: Similar to how Moodle can track unread posts for forums, what if instructors who are collaboratively designing a course could see a label for any activities , resources and section summaries that are new or updated since the last time they accessed the course. This would highlight which items have changed be another teacher or instructional designer working on the course. A list of deleted items somewhere could also be a useful part of the picture. Labels like "New", "Updated", "Deleted" is what I envision to the right of each item as a general rule. Looking to emulate some of the benefits of track changes in other platforms (Google Docs, etc.), this could help streamline the communication flow for the collaborative course design process. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: drag and drop questions on a small screen device
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, suppose a learning outcome of your course is "Be able to identify a bacteria on a microscope slide" or "Be able to recognise a church with a steeple on a map" If that is a learning outcome, then a question like drag-and-drop markers is ideal to assess it. However, it is fundamentally a visual task, so it is never going to be accessible to a blind user. So, we have to ask what we mean by these question types being accessible. They are in many ways as accessible as possible. For example, they do not require the use o a mouse, or touch-screen. They can all be done using only keyboard. That is one ADA requirement. There is a known problem with drag-and-drop into text. The labels are not as good as the could probably be, so it is not as easy to complete these questions while using a screen reader as perhaps it could be. However, Moodle's existing Cloze question type suffers the same problem, and I have never been able to work out a good solution. Suggestions welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Calculated Simple question type variables reset
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all - I have a faculty member who is having troubles editing Calculated Simple question types.  He indicates that when trying to edit any aspect of existing question, the variable limits are reset to 1 and 10, rendering the calculated answers incorrect because they don't match the originals.  This feels like a bug to me, but perhaps there's some aspect of the question type design that makes it a necessity?  I thought before filing a bug report I'd see if anyone here had seen similar behavior. To ensure I haven't misconstrued something, here's his original report to me: The bug present in this version of moodle is easily reproducible. It appears to be an error specific to the Calculated Simple type under the “Create a new question…” option in the Question Bank section of a course. When any question of this type is made you must set limits for the variables the question will use. The default setting for these variables is 1 to 10. If you modify these variables to fit your question and save, the question appears to work just fine with the variables you have set; however, if you go back and try to modify ANY characteristic of a question of this type ( name of question, a typo in the question text, the tolerance of answer that it is willing to accept, etc.), these variables revert back to the defaults of 1 to 10. This then renders the calculated answers incorrect, as they do not match the set put forward by the original calculations. I assume this is an error in either how the variables are stored, or how they are indexed to the particular question. Thanks much for any guidance you may have!  We're running Moodle 2.8.7+ Brian

ResponsesInList.Title: PHP inside SCORM
ResponsesInList.Text: In my website, the xml file for flash is dynamically generated using php by combining few other xml files, based on url. So, if url says course=1&module=5, then php will combine xml file for course 1 and xml file for module 5 to generate the resultant xml. Is it possible to convert this into SCORM format. The main challenge I am facing is the PHP will not work inside SCORM format and url based manipulation will also be difficult. Could anybody suggest a workaround for this please? -Many Thanks, Abhilash

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PHP inside SCORM
ResponsesInList.Text: SCORM packages are designed to be static/self-contained content. You cannot add PHP to SCORM packages. You could potentially use AICC HACP by setting up a server that hosts the content and uses AICC HACP to communicate results etc with the LMS but I haven't seen any useful documentation on how to do this on your own.

ResponsesInList.Title: Edit conflicts
ResponsesInList.Text: How does Moodle handle edit conflicts? If more than one person has edit rights to an item of content which can be edited, like a page or a lesson , what happens when more than one person attempts to edit the same item at the same time? Is the item locked for additional edits as long as it is open for one editor, or is it possible for two editors to have the item open simultaneously? In the latter case, what happens when they save? Does the first save get priority, or the last save, or does it crash? (It hasn't happened to me yet, but it could.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Edit conflicts
ResponsesInList.Text: Two people could have the same edit page open at the same time. In that case, whoever saves second 'wins'. Their changes are the ones that will persist. However, given how most Moodle sites are used, this is probably a very rare occurrence.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Edit conflicts
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, We will have to be careful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, I have this topic-based course in Moodle and I'm building up another one, also topic-based. I'd love to borrow some topics from my old one to use in my new one. Each topic is a bunch of quizzes plus a couple of pages with some reference information. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alexander I created a hidden course called "Warehouse" which is only accessible for teachers and above.  Usually staff create all materials there (or at least import them there if they put something together directly in a course).  Then if I need anything in a new course, I just import it from the Warehouse.  It's quick and easy, and you can use the topics in the warehouse course to create an index which will help you track things down.  Using the recent activity block in the course lets teachers know when new materials have been added and a forum allows for discussion about future wishes and requirements. Hope this helps, Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Andy, >> Then if I need anything in a new course, I just import it from the Warehouse.  It's quick and easy Could you please elaborate on how you do it? I have a course which I want to use later on as the Warehouse. How exactly do you transfer a topic from the Warehouse to other courses? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alexander, You open the course where you want to import the items to.  In the Administration block you select Import and then you choose your storage course.  Then you select the items you want from that course and import them. Hope this helps! Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a bunch, Andy, that does help oodles! Great feature I hadn't known before!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: You may also ask your site admin to install the Sharing Cart block. It does more or less what the import function but it is more handy to use.

ResponsesInList.Title: Usability Suggestion - Standard content in new courses
ResponsesInList.Text:
One of the barriers to usability for students is that resources in courses may be in very different places and have very different names. This would be improved if a system wide template course could be used to populate every new course. For example it might have content describing the plagiarism policy and links to the reading list.  This could be done by code that caused the template course to be backed up and restored into each new course. This might be something like for hand created courses in the edit.php file you would add ... $bc = new
backup_controller(backup::TYPE_1COURSE, $templatecourseid, backup::FORMAT_MOODLE, backup::INTERACTIVE_NO,
backup::MODE_IMPORT, $USER->id); Then execution code and $rc = new
restore_controller($backupid, $course->id, bla bla bla What do you think?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Usability Suggestion - Standard content in new courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Good idea, Marcus, but isn't that a template? I haven't tried it, but is setting up templates easy or not that straightforward in Moodle? I think most of us would be familiar with the idea of templates, long before we get ti know Moodle, so how difficult is it to extend that idea into our Moodle courses? EDIT: Then I find this in the Docs and after a quick scan see, that Admins are going to have to teach their course creators how to do that, then provide them with the agreed template. In an environment where such standardization is a demand of the workplace, it will work nicely, but where it is not, or where the people who are leaders and are not Moodlers, they are just not going to demand it. They wouldn't even understand the efficacy of such a solution, just looks complicated and for more than a few Admins, I suspect the same would apply. I work in an environment where "diversity" is "encouraged"... sort of... well- not really, it is actually "anything new is dangerous". For the Teachers... oh a Maths Moodle is not the same as a Humanities Moodle... they have different priorities and what worksd ... blah blah... into a round of endless blabbering descending into inaction and meaningless drivel. Or am I being too cynical?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Usability Suggestion - Standard content in new courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes it is a template, and oddly it is only when uploading a course with .CSV do you get content. With other ways of creating content, e.g. by hand or with authentication such as LDAP you only get the course settings (e.g. the format such as Topic or Date).  I suspect there are more courses created with those technologies than by CSV. With LDAP the course is created when the first person enrolled on the course logged in, zero teaching of course creators and so rather attractive to admins. You don't get template content when creating by hand either. I think it would be very easy for Admins to overdo the use of templates and there are only so many commonalities between subjects. Some examples that spring to my mind is having a link to a reading list and details of course re-take policies and contact details of course tutors. This would be blanks requiring completion once the course is created. It's easy to imagine some tutors forgetting to do it and ending up with text such as "Course Tutor Details go here" or similar, but you could do a database scan to nudge on these. " Or am I being too cynical? " Possibly, or you might be an experienced realist?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course overview takes me to news forum?

By default if you don't change your front page , this summary is visible on the front page. It links to the actual course page into which you add all the course activities . You are seeing a default News forum (which you can delete) and topic sections which have dates on them. You can get rid of the dates and the sections if you wish. Here is something to take a look at (version 2.8 of Moodle but still mostly relevant) Also - take a look at this documentation page for new administrators which I think is relevant to you: Guide for new administrators

ResponsesInList.Title: Charity organisation reaching out for suggestions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, As far as possible I've tried to find solutions to the issues I have but I'm just not finding the solutions I'm looking for. I've completely wrecked our sandbox a few times trying this and that. I also think I don't always have the terminology right when searching for solutions. So I thought I'd reach out and explain in layman's terms what I'm looking for. A bit of background of how we are using Moodle: We're a non-profit/charity delivering services to persons with disabilities. The bulk of our training is various internal medications related training, this is delivered to roughly 1000 people; and compliance training delivered to roughly 1600 people. After care workers have completed medications related training, the training remains relevant for 1 or 2 years, after which they will either do "refresher" training every 1 - 2 years OR they will redo the training course again. The compliance training is the same. This needs to reflect as a separate event of some kind. We need to have a track record of when they've completed the same training over. Currently our two biggest issues: - Objective : When a student has been enrolled they get an email sent to them telling them this. A link to the course would be great. - Issue : We don't want any kind of self-enrolment so the solutions out there don't seem to support the admin doing all the tasks. - Current workaround: Don't have one. Currently sending a manual email notification. - Objective: Our internal courses are valid for 1 or 2 years. - Issue: I don't seem to find a solution to make their yearly training to expire somehow in an efficient way. I hope I've explained my situation well enough, however I'm sure you can see it's not the usual way of using Moodle. Any suggestions are welcome. Cheers Steven

I understand how it can be changed through site administration for your whole college/institution's moodle theme to be changed. How does a student change their own personal theme? Alan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How does a student change their theme?
ResponsesInList.Text: A user can only change their theme if admin has turned on a setting that allows users to change their theme. Once that is on you will see an option in the profile to change theme.

ResponsesInList.Title: Best video format & software for mobile user (iphone) compatibility
ResponsesInList.Text: Summary: Which video format should I use in Moodle activities (e.g. html5) and what software (e.g. VideoStudio Pro X8) do users recommend to record these videos to ensure good usability across devices and operating systems, particularly basic iPhone users. Full: I am looking for a reasonably priced video solution and approach that is compatible with as many mobile and desktop users as possible (and also on the Moodle App, if possible). I'd like to avoid any poor UX approaches such as users having to install plug-ins, browsers, enabling features, etc. So, I'd like to know (1) what software to buy/ download and use and (2) what format to export. My research so far has led me to use VideoStudio Pro X8 and export to html5 as a best solution. My sense (unconfirmed) is that html5 typically uses neither javascript nor flash so will basically work on anything but has less functionality than most SCORM packages. So that is not a great answer, but a sufficient one. Sounds like there may exist SCORM approaches that don't use flash, and the best answer I have to this so far was this previous post ( https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=152379 )  but these seem a bit too technical or unverified.  VisualStudio can screen record, has good reviews, and is affordable. We're not doing a whole lot on that end so it seems more than enough for my needs. Thanks! Tom

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Best video format & software for mobile user (iphone) compatibility
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you tried avidemux (windows,linux,mac) or openshot (Linux only). Both free & open source just like moodle and linux. http://alternativeto.net/software/ulead-videostudio/?platform=linux http://fixounet.free.fr/avidemux/ http://www.openshot.org/download/ I would also like to hear from experienced users in video with moodle , as I have just started taking interest in this topic. I can't use videostudio being a linux user.
